analyze writing style and tone.

conversation.content:
I am going to paste different paragraphs that I’ve written. I want you to analyze and learn writing style and tone.                                                                                               
                                                  When American actress Edith Meiser (1898–1993) initially proposed the idea of Sherlock Holmes radio adaptations for an American audience in 1930, she was told it was “too old-fashioned” and prospective sponsors “wanted a streamlined sleuth.”Footnote1 She persisted, and the series ran from 1930 to 1948 (with some breaks), using a shifting cast of actors and underwritten by sponsors such as Washington Coffee and Chicago-based Household Finance. During its run, when the Conan Doyle estate tightly controlled any use of Sherlock Holmes material, the series earned Meiser the distinction of being the author of more original Sherlock Holmes stories than anyone apart from Arthur Conan Doyle himself. Meiser's radio scripts dramatized Conan Doyle’s stories and characters, and they also shaped audience understanding and expectations of genre as the older detective stories were translated into the modern medium of the interwar radio serial.Footnote2

Edith Meiser had the tenacity, background, and connections to launch the introduction of Conan Doyle’s fictional sleuth to radio. After graduating from Vassar in 1921, she joined a repertory theater company in Detroit before moving to New York. She married Tom McKnight, an advertising executive whose firm, McKnight and Jordan, also produced radio shows. In the male-dominated business of radio – a 1939 CBS press release on the serial focuses on her appearance, describing her as “tall and willowy,” with height and weight cited – Meiser became an accomplished radio script writer, landing a plum assignment of scripting 26 broadcasts for Helen Hayes in 1935.Footnote3 For the Holmes series, she eventually produced 104 original scripts, many of them rebroadcast, and she wrote a syndicated Sherlock Holmes comic strip in 1954–55. Ronald De Waal, creator of the well-known World Bibliography of Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson (1974), wrote to Meiser in 1972 that she “should be given the Sherlockian title of ‘The Woman’ [because she] contributed more to the world of Sherlock Holmes than any other member of [her] sex.”Footnote4 The Baker Street IrregularsFootnote5 invested Meiser in the initial group of six women admitted to the all-male bastion of the BSI in 1991, and yet only eight years earlier the noted collector John Bennett Shaw observed that “many Sherlockians are not aware of the contributions she's made to our field.”Footnote6

These Sherlockian tributes pleased Meiser, but readers of Feminist Modernist Studies may be more concerned by the fact that her name often does not appear in references to the Holmes radio serial. Given that Meiser initiated the project and was the sole script writer for many years, why is it now necessary to recover her contributions? Scanning both scholarship and popular sources referencing this radio serial, the names of the lead actors – the male voices listeners associated with the stories – and male scriptwriters occur frequently; one could say they dominate the credits. For more than a decade, notably, Meiser provided all scripts. Only as late as 1943 were other writers commissioned for scripts, most notably the male crime-fiction writers and critics Leslie Charteris and Anthony Boucher. References to Charteris and Boucher, alone or in combination, often imply ownership of the series with no mention of Meiser, thereby erasing the woman who created and sustained the radio serial throughout its life. Radio historian Patrick Murray notes that the male writers gave Professor Moriarty “a much wider role as a master criminal than in the Conan Doyle stories.”Footnote7 This shift tilts the episodes toward a more action-adventure direction, pulling the characters and plot lines farther away from detection. Meiser's scripts, in contrast, develop the intrinsic interest of the detective and thus contribute to subsequent developments in Sherlock Holmes adaptations.

Meiser's radio serial launched with a broadcast of “The Adventure of the Speckled Band” on 20 October 1930. Sherlock Holmes was voiced by the American actor William Gillette, internationally renowned for over a thousand early twentieth-century stage performances as Holmes. 1930 was the year of Arthur Conan Doyle’s death, whose reputation in the United States had suffered in the 1920s partly owing to his championing of spiritualism, including a public falling out with Harry Houdini on the subject. That may explain why in pursuit of her idea, Meiser reportedly had to order books from England to have the complete stories. In a 1936 interview, Meiser noted that “Sherlock is perfect air material. There are not too many clues [...] Sherlock has excellent radio pace. It's uncanny how smoothly it works out for radio adaptation. Conan Doyle had great vision.”Footnote8 Credit to her for her perception, borne out by the dramatizations of the original stories which she often lifted quite directly from Conan Doyle's text. Examining Meiser's history and the scripts she produced begins to answer the feminist intermodernist question of what happens when the “brand” of Holmes and Watson is translated into the American radio market of the 1930s and leads to recuperating Meiser as a significant popular-genre writer of the interwar period.

Initially, all of Meiser's scripts were dramatic adaptations of the original tales and then, with permission of the estate, she wrote new stories for Holmes and Watson. The new stories follow the pattern of later Holmes pastiches: they draw on the original stories to create a case named in passing, fill in backstory, or concoct further adventures for a character. For example, there is “The Adventure of the Typewritten Will,” which takes up Violet Smith from “the Solitary Cyclist” and creates a plot about a forged will; the solution hinges on details of typewriter technology and production chronology. Meiser sometimes used current events as a way of generating a new link to a Holmes story; these also provide hooks for listener interest. In the 1935 story, “Cherchez la Femme,” Meiser used current headlines speculating about Cleopatra’s mummy (“Mummy rumor irks Curators” was one 10 January 1935 news headline) to build a spinoff from “The Reigate Puzzle” in which Sherlock Holmes “reveals” to listeners the secret of Cleopatra’s irresistible appeal to men – hashish. That mystery summarily resolved, Cleopatra's remains are stashed in a nameless backwater Parisian museum.

Although we might expect the portrayal of Holmes to be the starting point for consideration of the radio serial’s role in bringing the great detective to American audiences, in fact what happens with Watson reveals more about the interplay among source material, the new medium, and its listeners. As David Trotter argues, even after radio established itself as a medium for “reportage, chronicle, and fiction, it retained its connective credentials [...] [R]adio spoke directly to the individual listener in her or his own home.”Footnote9 Meiser understood the consequences of the medium both technically and in terms of characterization and connection. Meiser's Watson serves the narrative functions he does in the Conan Doyle stories, but his persona shifts to adapt to the medium. By the series’ final years, Murray notes that “Watson was in fact becoming the dominant character.”Footnote10 In a 1983 interview, Meiser observed that the fan mail came to Watson, particularly during the Rathbone/Bruce years of 1939–46; “hardly anyone,” she said, “ever wrote directly to Holmes.”Footnote11

On the radio, Watson’s de facto role as intermediary between the audience and the great detective in Conan Doyle’s tales included activities such as plugging for sponsors and being the face of the program for viewer participation. In November 1931, those listening to “The Cardboard Box” were teased with the possibility of a radio version of The Hound of the Baskervilles. Over a glass of brandy, the announcer and Watson consider the “most famous and thrilling case of Sherlock Holmes’ entire career,” and the announcer invites listeners to “drop [Watson] a line – a post card will do – in care of the station to which you are now listening.” Watson exclaims, “I do hope they decide to let me do it!”Footnote12

Meiser's radio Watson, then, arguably becomes more modern as he flogs his Clipper Craft suit which “stays neat and natty”Footnote13 while dramatizing on air the dangers facing Holmes. Alison Light draws a contrast between Watson and Hastings, suggesting that Christie “sounds a modern note [...] an ironic, debunking one” in making Hastings “more of a stooge than a helpmeet” in contrast with the teasing respect accorded Watson.Footnote14 Meiser's radio Watson shifts in the direction described by Light, partly due to the nature of the (modernizing) medium. For instance, to those who criticized her Watson as “a bit of a sissy,” Meiser replied in an interview that “it was necessary [...] to have Watson always a bit nervous. Otherwise listeners never would know the risks Sherlock was taking.”Footnote15 Radio historian John Dunning claims that “as in the movies, Watson was something of a disappointment. In the mass media he never approached Conan Doyle’s intent – a man of high intelligence whose brain seemed small only in comparison with Holmes’ deductive genius.”Footnote16 Meiser's understanding that Watson is needed to establish scenes and to create suspense – things that Conan Doyle could construct by other means in his stories – advances recognition of his character not as a disappointment, but as a key figure for audience engagement. The demands of the modern medium shape Meiser's presentation of the character. I would argue, furthermore, that her radio Watson set expectations that were continued by Nigel Bruce's portly, bumbling Watson when first brought to film by Hollywood in 1939.Footnote17 Making these connections emphasizes Meiser's enduring contribution to shaping audience engagement with Holmes and Watson across multiple media and over many decades. As the quintessential English detective's “brand” has continued to evolve, the contributions of Edith Meiser deserve recognition. Not only did her intervention sustain and expand audience engagement with the stories, but her understanding of interwar audiences and the new medium of radio has had an enduring impact on the depiction of the detective's faithful Watson.

The writing style in this passage is informative and detailed, providing a wealth of historical and biographical information about Edith Meiser and the Sherlock Holmes radio adaptations she wrote. The tone is scholarly and authoritative, as the author analyzes Meiser's contributions to the series and situates it within the broader context of the interwar period and the emergence of radio as a medium. The writing is also analytical, as the author considers the ways in which Meiser adapted Conan Doyle's stories and characters to suit the demands of radio, and how her portrayal of Watson differed from that of the original stories. Overall, this passage demonstrates a careful attention to detail and a deep knowledge of the subject matter, conveyed in a clear and engaging style.

Women at Point Zero by Nawal El Saadawi is a powerful novel that explores the experiences of women living in a patriarchal society in Egypt. The novel is a feminist text that challenges traditional gender norms, and it foregrounds the experiences of women who are often marginalized and oppressed in Egyptian society. This essay will analyze Women at Point Zero within the theoretical framework of Chandra Mohanty's Under Western Eyes, examining how the novel highlights the ways in which women in Egypt are subject to oppression and how this oppression is perpetuated through Western feminist discourse.

In Under Western Eyes, Chandra Mohanty argues that Western feminist discourse often decontextualizes the experiences of women in the Global South, reducing them to a homogenous group characterized by victimhood and oppression. This discourse ultimately perpetuates the marginalization of these women by reinforcing Western hegemony and obscuring the complex and nuanced lived experiences of women in the Global South. Women at Point Zero is a text that critiques this Western feminist discourse by foregrounding the experiences of Egyptian women and exposing the complexities of their lived experiences.

One of the central themes in Women at Point Zero is the experience of sexual violence and its role in perpetuating patriarchal power structures. The protagonist, Firdaus, experiences sexual violence throughout her life and is ultimately pushed to the margins of Egyptian society as a result. Through Firdaus's experiences, El Saadawi critiques Western feminist discourse that reduces women in the Global South to passive victims, pointing out that women in Egypt often face violence not only from men but also from other women who enforce patriarchal norms. Firdaus's own mother, for example, repeatedly sells her to men as a child, perpetuating a cycle of violence and exploitation that she herself has experienced.

The novel also highlights the ways in which women in Egypt are marginalized through economic oppression. Throughout the novel, Firdaus experiences exploitation and poverty, working in low-paying jobs and ultimately turning to prostitution to survive. This economic marginalization is perpetuated by a patriarchal system that devalues the labor and contributions of women, making it difficult for them to achieve financial independence or escape poverty. In this way, El Saadawi criticizes Western feminist discourse that assumes that economic empowerment is a simple matter of job training and education, without acknowledging the systemic barriers that prevent women in the Global South from achieving financial stability.

Another important theme in Women at Point Zero is that of agency and resistance. Despite the numerous challenges that Firdaus faces throughout her life, she ultimately refuses to be defined by her experiences of victimization and actively resists patriarchal norms. In the final section of the novel, Firdaus achieves a sense of agency and power by refusing to submit to the patriarchal authority of the men around her, even at the cost of her own life. This theme of resistance is particularly significant in the context of Western feminist discourse, which often assumes that women in the Global South are passive victims without agency. El Saadawi's novel challenges this assumption by foregrounding the ways in which women in Egypt actively resist and subvert patriarchal norms.

In conclusion, Women at Point Zero is a powerful feminist novel that challenges traditional gender norms and foregrounds the experiences of marginalized women in Egypt. Within the theoretical framework of Chandra Mohanty's Under Western Eyes, the novel exposes the ways in which Western feminist discourse can perpetuate the marginalization of women in the Global South and obscures the complexities of their lived experiences. Through its exploration of themes such as sexual violence, economic oppression, and agency, the novel highlights the ways in which patriarchal power structures are perpetuated and the importance of actively resisting them. El Saadawi's work is a testament to the strength and resilience of women in the face of oppression and provides a powerful critique of Western feminist discourse that has too often erased the experiences of women in the Global South.

Using the writing style you just learned, write me a 1000-word, single idea essay on the novel women at point zero foregrounding in theoretical framework of chandra mohantays under western eyes

Title: Re-envisioning Female Identity in "Women at Point Zero" Through the Lens of Chandra Mohanty's "Under Western Eyes"

Introduction

Nawal El Saadawi's seminal novel, "Women at Point Zero," introduces readers to a powerful narrative of female oppression and resistance, as seen through the eyes of its protagonist, Firdaus. Firdaus, an imprisoned woman awaiting her execution in an Egyptian prison, encapsulates the cultural and political predicament faced by women in modern Egypt, as well as in the larger context of the Arab world. This essay aims to analyze "Women at Point Zero" by applying the theoretical framework proposed by Chandra Mohanty in her influential essay "Under Western Eyes," in which she critiques the Western feminist approach towards women's issues in the Third World. By utilizing Mohanty's framework, this essay will explore how the novel challenges the singular, monolithic representation of oppressed women in the Arab world and offers a more nuanced understanding of women's experiences in the complex patriarchal systems in which they exist.

Chandra Mohanty's "Under Western Eyes" and its Critique

In "Under Western Eyes," Chandra Mohanty critiques the process in which Western feminist discourses have historically constructed and perpetuated the image of "Third World woman" as a singular, homogenous category, characterized by passive victimhood in the face of patriarchal oppression. According to Mohanty, this representation not only essentializes and exoticizes women from the Third World but also furthers Western imperialism by establishing a relationship of superiority and subordination. Mohanty emphasizes the importance of understanding the diverse and context-specific experiences of women in the Third World and acknowledges the interrelations and intersections of gender, race, culture, and class that shape their lives. Mohanty's critique offers a valuable framework for analyzing "Women at Point Zero" and investigates how the novel subverts the monolithic representation of Arab women and emphasizes the complex and agency-filled experiences of its protagonist, Firdaus.

Foregrounding Firdaus: Breaking the Monolithic Representation

Nawal El Saadawi's "Women at Point Zero" presents the life story of Firdaus, who experiences various forms of oppression, marginalization, and violence throughout her life – from her traumatic childhood to her tumultuous relationships with men and the injustices she faces as a prostitute. Firdaus' story could easily be misconstrued as a classic representation of the oppressed Arab woman, fitting neatly within the essentialist framework critiqued by Mohanty. However, El Saadawi's nuanced portrayal of Firdaus complicates such an interpretation, emphasizing her agency and resistance even in the face of seemingly insurmountable odds.

One of the key elements in which El Saadawi dismantles the monolithic representation of Arab women is by foregrounding Firdaus' voice and consciousness throughout the novel. Firdaus is not only the central character in the novel but also its primary narrator, as much of the story unfolds through her perspective and memories. This narrative choice affirms the importance of Firdaus' subjective experiences and reinforces her individuality, actively resisting the erasure often encountered by women in the Arab world. Furthermore, Firdaus' sharp wit, keen observational skills, and introspection throughout the novel defy the stereotypical image of the passive, helpless Arab woman.

Moreover, in addition to her narrative and intellectual agency, Firdaus demonstrates a tangible resistance to the oppressive forces in her life. Her refusal to submit to the men who exploit her sexually and her eventual decision to kill a man who abuses her exemplify her capacity to challenge her subjugation. While her actions may not reflect a conventional form of feminist resistance or empowerment, they portray a complex and morally ambiguous struggle against oppressive patriarchal norms. This portrayal not only ruptures the singular image of the passive Arab woman but underscores the necessity of context-specific understanding of resistance and agency.

Intersectionality and the Complexity of Oppression

El Saadawi's novel powerfully illustrates the intersections of various forms of oppression – including gender, class, and economic – that shape Firdaus' life. In doing so, it aligns with Chandra Mohanty's insistence on acknowledging the complexity and interrelatedness of the systems that oppress women in the Third World. By highlighting the ways in which Firdaus is discriminated against not only as a woman but also as a poor, uneducated, and stigmatized individual, the novel moves beyond a simplistic, gender-centric analysis of her oppression and presents a more comprehensive understanding of her life.

Conclusion

In conclusion, Nawal El Saadawi's "Women at Point Zero," when read through the lens of Chandra Mohanty's "Under Western Eyes," exemplifies how the novel challenges the monolithic and reductionist representations of Arab women, offering a more nuanced and agency-filled account of its protagonist, Firdaus. Through foregrounding Firdaus' voice and consciousness, depicting her resistance to patriarchal oppression, and illustrating the complexity of the intersecting forces that shape her life, El Saadawi's novel effectively aligns with and enriches Mohanty's call for a more contextualized and diverse understanding of women's experiences in the Third World. In doing so, "Women at Point Zero" contributes to a broader and more inclusive feminist discourse that recognizes and celebrates the complexity and multiplicity of women's lives and struggles worldwide.

In the 1935 story, “Cherchez la Femme,” Meiser used current headlines speculating about Cleopatra’s mummy (“Mummy rumor irks Curators” was one 10 January 1935 news headline) to build a spinoff from “The Reigate Puzzle” in which Sherlock Holmes “reveals” to listeners the secret of Cleopatra’s irresistible appeal to men – hashish. That mystery summarily resolved, Cleopatra's remains are stashed in a nameless backwater Parisian museum.

Although we might expect the portrayal of Holmes to be the starting point for consideration of the radio serial’s role in bringing the great detective to American audiences, in fact what happens with Watson reveals more about the interplay among source material, the new medium, and its listeners. As David Trotter argues, even after radio established itself as a medium for “reportage, chronicle, and fiction, it retained its connective credentials [...] [R]adio spoke directly to the individual listener in her or his own home.”Footnote9 Meiser understood the consequences of the medium both technically and in terms of characterization and connection. Meiser's Watson serves the narrative functions he does in the Conan Doyle stories, but his persona shifts to adapt to the medium. By the series’ final years, Murray notes that “Watson was in fact becoming the dominant character.”Footnote10 In a 1983 interview, Meiser observed that the fan mail came to Watson, particularly during the Rathbone/Bruce years of 1939–46; “hardly anyone,” she said, “ever wrote directly to Holmes.”Footnote11

On the radio, Watson’s de facto role as intermediary between the audience and the great detective in Conan Doyle’s tales included activities such as plugging for sponsors and being the face of the program for viewer participation. In November 1931, those listening to “The Cardboard Box” were teased with the possibility of a radio version of The Hound of the Baskervilles. Over a glass of brandy, the announcer and Watson consider the “most famous and thrilling case of Sherlock Holmes’ entire career,” and the announcer invites listeners to “drop [Watson] a line – a post card will do – in care of the station to which you are now listening.” Watson exclaims, “I do hope they decide to let me do it!”Footnote12

Meiser's radio Watson, then, arguably becomes more modern as he flogs his Clipper Craft suit which “stays neat and natty”Footnote13 while dramatizing on air the dangers facing Holmes. Alison Light draws a contrast between Watson and Hastings, suggesting that Christie “sounds a modern note [...] an ironic, debunking one” in making Hastings “more of a stooge than a helpmeet” in contrast with the teasing respect accorded Watson.Footnote14 Meiser's radio Watson shifts in the direction described by Light, partly due to the nature of the (modernizing) medium. For instance, to those who criticized her Watson as “a bit of a sissy,” Meiser replied in an interview that “it was necessary [...] to have Watson always a bit nervous. Otherwise listeners never would know the risks Sherlock was taking.”Footnote15 Radio historian John Dunning claims that “as in the movies, Watson was something of a disappointment. In the mass media he never approached Conan Doyle’s intent – a man of high intelligence whose brain seemed small only in comparison with Holmes’ deductive genius.”Footnote16 Meiser's understanding that Watson is needed to establish scenes and to create suspense – things that Conan Doyle could construct by other means in his stories – advances recognition of his character not as a disappointment, but as a key figure for audience engagement. The demands of the modern medium shape Meiser's presentation of the character. I would argue, furthermore, that her radio Watson set expectations that were continued by Nigel Bruce's portly, bumbling Watson when first brought to film by Hollywood in 1939.Footnote17 Making these connections emphasizes Meiser's enduring contribution to shaping audience engagement with Holmes and Watson across multiple media and over many decades. As the quintessential English detective's “brand” has continued to evolve, the contributions of Edith Meiser deserve recognition. Not only did her intervention sustain and expand audience engagement with the stories, but her understanding of interwar audiences and the new medium of radio has had an enduring impact on the depiction of the detective's faithful Watson.

After analyzing the provided paragraphs, the writing style can be described as academic, analytic, and informative. The tone is formal and professional, using scholarly language and citations to support the points made. The paragraphs seem to be discussing the influence of Edith Meiser on the Sherlock Holmes radio adaptations and examining her contributions to the development of the series and the portrayal of the characters. The author also delves into the impact of radio as a medium of storytelling and how Meiser's adaptations shaped the perceptions and expectations of the characters and the detective genre.

Title: Challenging Western Feminist Perspectives in Nawal El Saadawi's "Woman at Point Zero"

Introduction

Nawal El Saadawi's groundbreaking 1975 novel, "Woman at Point Zero," explores the intersection of patriarchy, oppression, and female agency in a postcolonial Egyptian context. The novel tells the harrowing story of Firdaus, a woman imprisoned and sentenced to death for her defiance against a male-dominated society. To better understand and appreciate the novel's significance, it is crucial to examine it through the lens of Chandra Mohanty's framework as presented in her influential essay, "Under Western Eyes: Feminist Scholarship, and Colonial Discourses" (1988). Mohanty's framework critiques Western feminist scholarship's tendency to homogenize and essentialize the experiences of "Third World Women" and calls for a more context-specific analysis. This essay argues that "Woman at Point Zero" challenges Western feminist perspectives by highlighting the unique struggles and resistance of a marginalized Egyptian woman. 

Mohanty's Theoretical Framework and Its Relevance to "Woman at Point Zero"

Chandra Mohanty's "Under Western Eyes" is a foundational text in postcolonial feminism, as it exposes the problematic ways in which Western feminist scholars have discursively constructed the image of the oppressed, passive, Third World Woman. Mohanty argues that this monolithic representation eliminates the specific historical, cultural, and political contexts of women's experiences, thereby reinforcing the colonialist assumption of the superiority of Western knowledge and ignoring the agency and resistance of Non-Western women. In this sense, Mohanty's critique can be effectively applied to the analysis of "Woman at Point Zero" to foreground Firdaus's unique experience, which transcends the reductionist Western feminist paradigms.

Narrative Structure and Challenging Western Stereotypes

The narrative structure of "Woman at Point Zero" plays a crucial role in challenging Western feminist assumptions about Non-Western women. The novel is framed through the perspective of a female psychiatrist named Nawal El Saadawi, who visits Firdaus in prison shortly before her execution. Despite their differences in social status, education, and life experiences, El Saadawi is drawn to Firdaus's story, as it exposes the similarities they share as women struggling against patriarchy. This narrative structure enables a deep exploration of Firdaus's life, which defies Western feminist categorizations.

Firdaus's story reveals her continuous acts of rebellion against the oppressive forces in her life. From her traumatic childhood and early experiences of sexual violence to her subjugation in a forced marriage, Firdaus's struggles resonate with the issues faced by women globally. However, her distinctive response to these struggles positions her as a unique agent of resistance who defies the Western feminist assumptions of passivity and victimhood. Firdaus's decision to become a sex worker is a conscious choice to reclaim power in a world where men exploit women for their bodies. By becoming a high-class prostitute, she gains money, social connections, and, importantly, a sense of control over her life that challenges the Western gaze on Third World Women as powerless victims.

Challenging Western Feminism Through Context-Specific Struggles

El Saadawi's portrayal of Firdaus questions the homogenizing tendencies of Western feminism in another significant way: by emphasizing the importance of acknowledging the specific socio-cultural context of women's experiences. Unlike Western feminist approaches that often focus on issues of political representation,Equal rights to employment, and reproductive rights, "Woman at Point Zero" highlights the struggles faced by Egyptian women in terms of illiteracy, poverty, and tradition-bound patriarchal practices. 

Throughout the novel, we see Firdaus trying to assert her autonomy in her personal and professional life by fighting against prevalent customs like genital mutilation and forced marriage. However, her sense of accomplishment is often undermined by her increasing awareness of the institutionalized patriarchy that pervades Egyptian society. For instance, Firdaus's education empowers her to some extent, but it does not allow her to escape the control and manipulation of male figures in her life, such as her abusive husband and exploitative pimp. This example underscores the significance of contextualizing women's experiences within the specific historical, cultural, and political landscapes in which they occur and highlights the oversimplification of Western feminist perspectives. 

Conclusion

Nawal El Saadawi's "Woman at Point Zero" serves as a powerful reminder of the importance of interrogating the ethnocentric assumptions that often permeate Western feminist scholarship. By applying Chandra Mohanty's theoretical framework to the analysis of the novel, we can recognize the unique struggles and forms of resistance embodied by Firdaus, an Egyptian woman who defies the reductionist narratives of Third World Women's oppression. The novel invites its readers to critically engage with and appreciate the complexities of women's experiences in a non-Western context, ultimately enriching our understanding of global gender relations and advocating for a more inclusive feminist discourse.

the writing style should be academic and formal, with a focus on detail and analysis. Complex vocabulary and sentence structures are to be used, including varied punctuation and transition words. The tone must be informative and authoritative. moreover, The writing style should be coherent, consistent, and organized. and the paragraphs must be logically structured to create a clear and progressive flow of ideas.                                                                                                                                                 
                                                    “In the west, women left no stone unturned in the construction of the orientalist discourse, even though male scholars made up most of it. There is a ‘persistent trope’ in the West in general and Western feminism in particular, where Third-World women are frequently seen and stereotyped as helpless, submissive, dependent, and oppressive beings. In reality, Western feminists utilized the stereotypical image of women from third-world nations to contribute to the ideological project of the empire and promote the differences between Occidental and Oriental women, the primitive and the civilized, the spiritual and the rational, the weak and the powerful, while dressing up to rescue Third-World women from the plight of patriarchy and in their quest for liberation and development. They boasted about their own political rights and power while acting as agents of progress and enlightenment for Third-World women. According to Abu-Lughod (2002), “projects of saving other women depend on and reinforce a sense of superiority by Westerners, a form of arrogance that deserves to be challenged.” (789) However, even after donning the attire to rescue Third-World women, whom they saw as worse off than themselves, West women frequently “overstepped indigenous women’s subject position and sense of agency.” (Syed and Ali 352) Western feminists disregarded the effect of contextual factors on Third-World women. The women in the Third World have been portrayed and understood through the lens of Western feminists and viewers with no regard whatsoever and due consideration of local customs, culture, history, language, education, traditions, family, society, religion, race, and class, polity, and economy. They see Third-World women as a single, homogenous group with the same issues and requirements as women in the West. Moreover, they presumptively believe that all women across the world possess the same power and strength to fight against the implicit patriarchy and male-dominated culture they live in. (Mahmoud and Sarhan, 2011, 35)”
The paradigmatic

construction of Third-World women in the Orientalist discourse warrants a comprehensive analysis, refuting the hegemonic assertions that seek to define and subjugate these women. This essay delves into the imbrications of gender, culture, and power in shaping the portrayal of Third-World women by Western feminists and scrutinizes the underlying ideological motives behind such representations.

To begin with, the colonial legacy and its orientalist ramifications cannot be extricated from the discussion of Western feminism's perception of Third-World women. The latter's portrayal as victims of the oppressive patriarchal system is undeniably rooted in the postcolonial milieu, wherein colonial powers sought to justify their dominion by undermining the “Other's” culture and presenting themselves as benevolent saviors. Spivak (1988) elucidates this notion through her analysis of “White men saving brown women from brown men,” which encapsulates the imperialist endeavor to subdue native cultures under the façade of women's emancipation (297). Consequently, the West's self-aggrandizement not only diminishes Third-World women's agency but also belittles the complexity and heterogeneity of their experiences and struggles.

Furthermore, Third-World women are often essentialized in the Western feminist discourse, reduced to caricatures bereft of historical and cultural specificities. This decontextualization not only reinforces the binaries of East and West, perpetuating the superiority of the latter but also obfuscates the intersectionality of race, class, religion, and gender in shaping women's lived realities in non-Western societies. Therefore, the insistence on a monolithic understanding of Third-World women bolsters the pretense of Western feminists as harbingers of progress and enlightenment, thereby rationalizing and perpetuating the imperialist project.

Notwithstanding the aforementioned critiques, it is crucial to recognize the diversity of voices within Western feminism and avoid the fallacy of homogenizing it as a singular, monolithic entity. There exist critiques of the Orientalist discourse within the Western feminist tradition itself; for instance, the works of scholars like Mohanty (1988) and hooks (1981) have cogently critiqued the Eurocentric tendencies pervasive in mainstream feminist discourses. Hence, while analyzing the negative implications of Western feminists' portrayal of Third-World women, it is imperative to nuance the discussion and acknowledge the multiplicity of perspectives within the Western feminist domain.

In conclusion, the relationship between Western feminism and Third-World women is fraught with power dynamics and ideological implications that must be unraveled and contested. Deconstructing the pervasive Orientalist stereotypes requires dismantling the hegemonic structures of knowledge production and embracing a more inclusive, contextualized, and intersectional understanding of women's experiences and agency across the globe. The onus lies on both Western and non-Western feminists to engage in transnational dialogues, fostering solidarity and understanding while acknowledging the legitimacy and sovereignty of diverse voices and perspectives.

I am going to paste different paragraphs that I’ve written. I want you to analyze and learn writing style and tone.                                                                                Although it was difficult for me to find substantial archival documentation about twentieth century Spanish women writers while conducting research during the summer of 2019, I noticed their presence everywhere I went in Madrid, Seville, and Málaga. Writers like Amanda Junquera and Carmen Conde and visual artists like Maruja Mallo and Delhy Tejero were heavily involved in Silver Age (1898–1939) cultural production in these Spanish cities, alongside avant-garde writers like Federico García Lorca, Rafael Alberti, and Vicente Aleixandre. During my stay in each city, I identified the apartments where women writers once lived, visited the cafés and intellectual institutions where they gathered, and discussed their lives as an attendee at the “Modernity and the Avant-Garde in Spain: A Debate from the Perspectives of the United States and Spain” symposium at the Residencia de Estudiantes (Students’ Residence) in Madrid.Footnote1 While critics have attempted to include women in the literary canon by comparing their productivity to that of their male colleagues, this approach relies too heavily on physical documentation and does not take into consideration the difficulties women faced in gaining recognition as writers. There is, however, significant non-material documentation of the cultural milieu of Silver Age Spain in memories of and about women writers, the tertulias (literary gatherings) they held, and the collaborations they forged. During my trip, I interviewed Alejandro Sanz and Emilio Calderón about Vicente Aleixandre's life in Velintonia to construct a history of how writers inhabited the house, and I used Google Maps to pin locations not listed with historical plaques. To effect change on the literary historiography of Silver Age Spain, one must thus question the reliance on material evidence preserved in archives as a precondition of literary achievement.

Tània Balló's three Las Sinsombrero documentaries consider a different set of variables, namely social gatherings and community building among modern women (“las modernas”), to narrate their life stories beyond what has been inscribed on physical documents.Footnote2 Fellow avant-garde artist Ramón Gómez de la Serna gave a name to the phenomenon called “el sinsombrerismo,” a metaphor for rebellious avant-garde women of the 1920s who scandalously removed their hats in public.Footnote3 In her 2015, 2019, and 2021 Las Sinsombrero documentaries, Balló pays homage to dozens of modern women who were socially and artistically active during this period but whose contributions were left unacknowledged for decades. The memory of “las Sinsombrero” and their social networks survive in urban spaces, and new methods of documenting their lives and work are needed. Feminist researchers of Spanish modernism like Nuria Capdevila-Argüelles and Gemma Santiago Alonso have shown that the task of proving female participation in literary and cultural activities cannot be completed solely by conducting archival research given the inaccessibility or disappearance of material documentation created prior to the Spanish Civil War (1936–1939).Footnote4 Given that there is a wealth of non-material documentation for women's lived experiences within cultural networks, as I found in tracing the spaces through which they moved, I propose that Maurizio Ferraris's concept of “social objects” within documentality provides a needed point of entry for conducting research into the network of collaborations within which “las Sinsombrero” worked. Applying this theoretical framework to the history of locations like Velintonia allows scholars and cultural activists to reconcile memories of both documented male writers and the formative gatherings of understudied female inhabitants.

Upon analyzing the given text, it is evident that the writing style and tone used are academic, engaging, and informative. The author embarks on a thorough investigation of twentieth-century Spanish women writers, referencing various literary figures and research methods. There is a clear focus on detail and analysis, delving into archives, interviews, and exploring documentary evidence to enrich the discussion on the underrepresentation and achievements of these women during the Silver Age in Spain. Additionally, the tone conveys authority yet remains accessible, inviting the reader to engage with the topic and its historical context.

The complexity of the vocabulary used is noteworthy, employing terms specific to the field of study, such as "tertulias," "avant-garde," and "literary historiography." Moreover, the author employs a variety of sentence structures, incorporating transition words and a range of punctuation marks to create a coherent flow of ideas. The text demonstrates the capacity for critical thinking, as the author questions traditional research methodologies and introduces alternative theoretical frameworks like Maurizio Ferraris's concept of "social objects" within documentality.

The structure of the paragraphs demonstrates coherence, organization, and logical progression of ideas. The introduction sets the stage for discussing the experiences and contributions of Spanish women writers during the Silver Age. Subsequently, the author delves into the challenges faced by researchers due to the scarcity of physical documentation related to these women, suggesting the importance of analyzing non-material documentation like social gatherings and memories. The author substantiates the claims by referencing Tània Balló's documentaries and the works of feminist researchers like Nuria Capdevila-Argüelles and Gemma Santiago Alonso, providing a comprehensive view of the existing literature on the subject.

In conclusion, the writing style, tone, and organization of the provided text epitomize the qualities of a well-researched, academic, and engaging piece of writing. The author skillfully navigates the complexities of the subject matter, employing a rich vocabulary and employing a diverse range of sentence structures to create a compelling and informative narrative that invites the reader to reconsider traditional historiographic approaches and embrace more inclusive perspectives.

In the west, women left no stone unturned in the construction of the orientalist discourse, even though male scholars made up most of it. There is a ‘persistent trope’ in the West in general and Western feminism in particular, where Third-World women are frequently seen and stereotyped as helpless, submissive, dependent, and oppressive beings. In reality, Western feminists utilized the stereotypical image of women from third-world nations to contribute to the ideological project of the empire and promote the differences between Occidental and Oriental women, the primitive and the civilized, the spiritual and the rational, the weak and the powerful, while dressing up to rescue Third-World women from the plight of patriarchy and in their quest for liberation and development. They boasted about their own political rights and power while acting as agents of progress and enlightenment for Third-World women. According to Abu-Lughod (2002), “projects of saving other women depend on and reinforce a sense of superiority by Westerners, a form of arrogance that deserves to be challenged.” (789) However, even after donning the attire to rescue Third-World women, whom they saw as worse off than themselves, West women frequently “overstepped indigenous women’s subject position and sense of agency.” (Syed and Ali 352) Western feminists disregarded the effect of contextual factors on Third-World women. The women in the Third World have been portrayed and understood through the lens of Western feminists and viewers with no regard whatsoever and due consideration of local customs, culture, history, language, education, traditions, family, society, religion, race, and class, polity, and economy. They see Third-World women as a single, homogenous group with the same issues and requirements as women in the West. Moreover, they presumptively believe that all women across the world possess the same power and strength to fight against the implicit patriarchy and male-dominated culture they live in. (Mahmoud and Sarhan, 2011, 35)

The Orientalist Gaze: A Critical Examination of Western Feminism's Depiction of Third-World Women

The consumption and perpetuation of orientalist discourses in the West are incontrovertible, and as the given paragraph elucidates, women have been decidedly implicated in the construction of such discourses. Western feminists have persistently evoked the trope of Third-World women as helpless, submissive, and oppressive figures, inextricably tied to their supposedly primitive and irrational cultural milieu. This essay ventures to dissect this orientalist representation of non-western women and scrutinize its underlying motives, emphasizing the discrepancies and prejudices embedded in such a portrayal. Utilizing an academic and formal writing style, the analysis will focus on three primary aspects: the ideological underpinnings of Western feminism's homogenizing tendencies, the complexities of Third-World women's experiences often overshadowed by orientalist narratives, and the importance of acknowledging the agency and subjectivity of these women.

Firstly, it is crucial to foreground the ideological dimensions that govern Western feminism's depiction of Third-World women. Imbued with a Eurocentric worldview, the western feminist project entails a rhetoric of salvation that is contingent upon the perceived inferiority of non-western women. This notion of inferiority serves to underscore the presumed superiority of Western culture and values, thereby legitimating the role of Western feminists as harbingers of progress and enlightenment. As Abu-Lughod (2002) eloquently asserts, such "projects of saving other women depend on and reinforce a sense of superiority by Westerners, a form of arrogance that deserves to be challenged" (789). Consequently, Western feminists' insistence on rescuing Third-World women from the purported afflictions of patriarchy concomitantly reinforces the binaries of Occidental and Oriental, civilized and primitive, rational and spiritual. This dialectical dynamic ultimately engenders an oversimplified and reductive portrayal of non-western women that veils the complexities of their lived realities.

The second aspect to be underscored in countering the persistent trope of Third-World women as a monolithic and homogenous entity is the recognition of the intricacies and multifaceted nuances in their experiences. As Mahmoud and Sarhan (2011) argue, Western feminists' myopic understanding of non-western women often overlooks the myriad contextual factors that inform their lives, such as local customs, culture, history, language, education, traditions, family, society, religion, race, class, polity, and economy (35). By disregarding these contextual factors, Western feminists not only obscure the heterogeneity of Third-World women's experiences but also perpetuate an orientalist lens that reinforces their subjugation to patriarchal structures. Moreover, such a depiction tacitly disregards the resistance and resilience demonstrated by non-western women in their struggles against the manifold forms of oppression they encounter.

Lastly, it is crucial to emphasize the importance of recognizing the agency and subjectivity of Third-World women, as opposed to subscribing to the occidental view that denies them the status of active agents within their socio-cultural milieu. As Syed and Ali (2011) underscore, Western feminists often "overstep indigenous women's subject position and sense of agency" (352), thereby undermining their capacity to negotiate, challenge, and transform the power dynamics governing their lives. By negating the agency of non-western women, Western feminists not only further entrench the trope of the subjugated Third-World woman but also elide the myriad ways in which these women exercise their autonomy and forge resistance strategies. In so doing, they inadvertently deny non-western women their rightful place within the global struggle for gender equality.

In conclusion, the orientalist gaze that permeates Western feminism's depiction of Third-World women warrants a thorough and critical examination. By unmasking the ideological underpinnings of this reductive portrayal, recognizing the complexities of non-western women's experiences, and acknowledging their agency and subjectivity, the discourse on gender equality can aspire to be genuinely inclusive and equitable. It is incumbent upon scholars, activists, and thinkers to instigate a transformative dialogue that eschews the orientalist trope and embraces the rich, diverse, and multi-dimensional realities of women from diverse cultural backgrounds. In this vein, dismantling the orientalist discourse constitutes not only an epistemological endeavor but also an ethical imperative for the pursuit of a more just and egalitarian world.

                                                   When American actress Edith Meiser (1898–1993) initially proposed the idea of Sherlock Holmes radio adaptations for an American audience in 1930, she was told it was “too old-fashioned” and prospective sponsors “wanted a streamlined sleuth.”Footnote1 She persisted, and the series ran from 1930 to 1948 (with some breaks), using a shifting cast of actors and underwritten by sponsors such as Washington Coffee and Chicago-based Household Finance. During its run, when the Conan Doyle estate tightly controlled any use of Sherlock Holmes material, the series earned Meiser the distinction of being the author of more original Sherlock Holmes stories than anyone apart from Arthur Conan Doyle himself. Meiser's radio scripts dramatized Conan Doyle’s stories and characters, and they also shaped audience understanding and expectations of genre as the older detective stories were translated into the modern medium of the interwar radio serial.Footnote2

Edith Meiser had the tenacity, background, and connections to launch the introduction of Conan Doyle’s fictional sleuth to radio. After graduating from Vassar in 1921, she joined a repertory theater company in Detroit before moving to New York. She married Tom McKnight, an advertising executive whose firm, McKnight and Jordan, also produced radio shows. In the male-dominated business of radio – a 1939 CBS press release on the serial focuses on her appearance, describing her as “tall and willowy,” with height and weight cited – Meiser became an accomplished radio script writer, landing a plum assignment of scripting 26 broadcasts for Helen Hayes in 1935.Footnote3 For the Holmes series, she eventually produced 104 original scripts, many of them rebroadcast, and she wrote a syndicated Sherlock Holmes comic strip in 1954–55. Ronald De Waal, creator of the well-known World Bibliography of Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson (1974), wrote to Meiser in 1972 that she “should be given the Sherlockian title of ‘The Woman’ [because she] contributed more to the world of Sherlock Holmes than any other member of [her] sex.”Footnote4 The Baker Street IrregularsFootnote5 invested Meiser in the initial group of six women admitted to the all-male bastion of the BSI in 1991, and yet only eight years earlier the noted collector John Bennett Shaw observed that “many Sherlockians are not aware of the contributions she's made to our field.”Footnote6

These Sherlockian tributes pleased Meiser, but readers of Feminist Modernist Studies may be more concerned by the fact that her name often does not appear in references to the Holmes radio serial. Given that Meiser initiated the project and was the sole script writer for many years, why is it now necessary to recover her contributions? Scanning both scholarship and popular sources referencing this radio serial, the names of the lead actors – the male voices listeners associated with the stories – and male scriptwriters occur frequently; one could say they dominate the credits. For more than a decade, notably, Meiser provided all scripts. Only as late as 1943 were other writers commissioned for scripts, most notably the male crime-fiction writers and critics Leslie Charteris and Anthony Boucher. References to Charteris and Boucher, alone or in combination, often imply ownership of the series with no mention of Meiser, thereby erasing the woman who created and sustained the radio serial throughout its life. Radio historian Patrick Murray notes that the male writers gave Professor Moriarty “a much wider role as a master criminal than in the Conan Doyle stories.”Footnote7 This shift tilts the episodes toward a more action-adventure direction, pulling the characters and plot lines farther away from detection. Meiser's scripts, in contrast, develop the intrinsic interest of the detective and thus contribute to subsequent developments in Sherlock Holmes adaptations.

Meiser's radio serial launched with a broadcast of “The Adventure of the Speckled Band” on 20 October 1930. Sherlock Holmes was voiced by the American actor William Gillette, internationally renowned for over a thousand early twentieth-century stage performances as Holmes. 1930 was the year of Arthur Conan Doyle’s death, whose reputation in the United States had suffered in the 1920s partly owing to his championing of spiritualism, including a public falling out with Harry Houdini on the subject. That may explain why in pursuit of her idea, Meiser reportedly had to order books from England to have the complete stories. In a 1936 interview, Meiser noted that “Sherlock is perfect air material. There are not too many clues [...] Sherlock has excellent radio pace. It's uncanny how smoothly it works out for radio adaptation. Conan Doyle had great vision.”Footnote8 Credit to her for her perception, borne out by the dramatizations of the original stories which she often lifted quite directly from Conan Doyle's text. Examining Meiser's history and the scripts she produced begins to answer the feminist intermodernist question of what happens when the “brand” of Holmes and Watson is translated into the American radio market of the 1930s and leads to recuperating Meiser as a significant popular-genre writer of the interwar period.

Initially, all of Meiser's scripts were dramatic adaptations of the original tales and then, with permission of the estate, she wrote new stories for Holmes and Watson. The new stories follow the pattern of later Holmes pastiches: they draw on the original stories to create a case named in passing, fill in backstory, or concoct further adventures for a character. For example, there is “The Adventure of the Typewritten Will,” which takes up Violet Smith from “the Solitary Cyclist” and creates a plot about a forged will; the solution hinges on details of typewriter technology and production chronology. Meiser sometimes used current events as a way of generating a new link to a Holmes story; these also provide hooks for listener interest. In the 1935 story, “Cherchez la Femme,” Meiser used current headlines speculating about Cleopatra’s mummy (“Mummy rumor irks Curators” was one 10 January 1935 news headline) to build a spinoff from “The Reigate Puzzle” in which Sherlock Holmes “reveals” to listeners the secret of Cleopatra’s irresistible appeal to men – hashish. That mystery summarily resolved, Cleopatra's remains are stashed in a nameless backwater Parisian museum.

Although we might expect the portrayal of Holmes to be the starting point for consideration of the radio serial’s role in bringing the great detective to American audiences, in fact what happens with Watson reveals more about the interplay among source material, the new medium, and its listeners. As David Trotter argues, even after radio established itself as a medium for “reportage, chronicle, and fiction, it retained its connective credentials [...] [R]adio spoke directly to the individual listener in her or his own home.”Footnote9 Meiser understood the consequences of the medium both technically and in terms of characterization and connection. Meiser's Watson serves the narrative functions he does in the Conan Doyle stories, but his persona shifts to adapt to the medium. By the series’ final years, Murray notes that “Watson was in fact becoming the dominant character.”Footnote10 In a 1983 interview, Meiser observed that the fan mail came to Watson, particularly during the Rathbone/Bruce years of 1939–46; “hardly anyone,” she said, “ever wrote directly to Holmes.”Footnote11

On the radio, Watson’s de facto role as intermediary between the audience and the great detective in Conan Doyle’s tales included activities such as plugging for sponsors and being the face of the program for viewer participation. In November 1931, those listening to “The Cardboard Box” were teased with the possibility of a radio version of The Hound of the Baskervilles. Over a glass of brandy, the announcer and Watson consider the “most famous and thrilling case of Sherlock Holmes’ entire career,” and the announcer invites listeners to “drop [Watson] a line – a post card will do – in care of the station to which you are now listening.” Watson exclaims, “I do hope they decide to let me do it!”Footnote12

Meiser's radio Watson, then, arguably becomes more modern as he flogs his Clipper Craft suit which “stays neat and natty”Footnote13 while dramatizing on air the dangers facing Holmes. Alison Light draws a contrast between Watson and Hastings, suggesting that Christie “sounds a modern note [...] an ironic, debunking one” in making Hastings “more of a stooge than a helpmeet” in contrast with the teasing respect accorded Watson.Footnote14 Meiser's radio Watson shifts in the direction described by Light, partly due to the nature of the (modernizing) medium. For instance, to those who criticized her Watson as “a bit of a sissy,” Meiser replied in an interview that “it was necessary [...] to have Watson always a bit nervous. Otherwise listeners never would know the risks Sherlock was taking.”Footnote15 Radio historian John Dunning claims that “as in the movies, Watson was something of a disappointment. In the mass media he never approached Conan Doyle’s intent – a man of high intelligence whose brain seemed small only in comparison with Holmes’ deductive genius.”Footnote16 Meiser's understanding that Watson is needed to establish scenes and to create suspense – things that Conan Doyle could construct by other means in his stories – advances recognition of his character not as a disappointment, but as a key figure for audience engagement. The demands of the modern medium shape Meiser's presentation of the character. I would argue, furthermore, that her radio Watson set expectations that were continued by Nigel Bruce's portly, bumbling Watson when first brought to film by Hollywood in 1939.Footnote17 Making these connections emphasizes Meiser's enduring contribution to shaping audience engagement with Holmes and Watson across multiple media and over many decades. As the quintessential English detective's “brand” has continued to evolve, the contributions of Edith Meiser deserve recognition. Not only did her intervention sustain and expand audience engagement with the stories, but her understanding of interwar audiences and the new medium of radio has had an enduring impact on the depiction of the detective's faithful Watson.

The writing style and tone of the text is predominantly academic, informative, and analytical. The text uses a formal language with precise word choice and sentence structure, and relies heavily on footnote citations to provide proper credit to sources and historical information. The author thoroughly discusses the contributions of a particular figure, Edith Meiser, to the adaptations of Sherlock Holmes stories on the radio and establishes her significance in the wider context of the popularization of the character and brand. There is also a focus on feminist perspectives, as the author emphasizes the underrecognition of Meiser's work in the male-dominated field of radio and the overall Sherlock Holmes adaptations. The tone is assertive but fair, as the author critically examines the contribution of Meiser to the success of the radio series and the shifting portrayal of Watson's character within the adaptations, while also highlighting the various ways Meiser's work has been unfairly overlooked or marginalized.

Now write the below paras in the same writing style you just learned            "In the west, women left no stone unturned in the construction of the orientalist discourse, even though male scholars made up most of it. There is a ‘persistent trope’ in the West in general and Western feminism in particular, where Third-World women are frequently seen and stereotyped as helpless, submissive, dependent, and oppressive beings. In reality, Western feminists utilized the stereotypical image of women from third-world nations to contribute to the ideological project of the empire and promote the differences between Occidental and Oriental women, the primitive and the civilized, the spiritual and the rational, the weak and the powerful, while dressing up to rescue Third-World women from the plight of patriarchy and in their quest for liberation and development. They boasted about their own political rights and power while acting as agents of progress and enlightenment for Third-World women. According to Abu-Lughod (2002), “projects of saving other women depend on and reinforce a sense of superiority by Westerners, a form of arrogance that deserves to be challenged.” (789) However, even after donning the attire to rescue Third-World women, whom they saw as worse off than themselves, West women frequently “overstepped indigenous women’s subject position and sense of agency.” (Syed and Ali 352) Western feminists disregarded the effect of contextual factors on Third-World women. The women in the Third World have been portrayed and understood through the lens of Western feminists and viewers with no regard whatsoever and due consideration of local customs, culture, history, language, education, traditions, family, society, religion, race, and class, polity, and economy. They see Third-World women as a single, homogenous group with the same issues and requirements as women in the West. Moreover, they presumptively believe that all women across the world possess the same power and strength to fight against the implicit patriarchy and male-dominated culture they live in. (Mahmoud and Sarhan, 2011, 35)

In the occidental world, female scholars actively contributed to the construction of orientalist discourse, despite the majority of its constituents being male. There exists a 'persistent trope' within both Western culture and feminism, in which women from the Third World are recurrently portrayed and stereotyped as submissive, passive, and oppressed figures. Contrary to this image, Western feminists employed such stereotypes of Third-World women to support the ideological project underpinning imperialism, accentuating the distinctions between the Occident and Orient - the primitive versus the civilized, the spiritual versus the rational, and the weak versus the powerful. Simultaneously, they sought to rescue Third-World women from the clutches of patriarchal oppression, in pursuit of progress and emancipation.

Boasting their own political rights and power, Western feminists positioned themselves as agents of enlightenment for their Third-World counterparts. Abu-Lughod (2002) contends that "projects of saving other women depend on and reinforce a sense of superiority by Westerners, a form of arrogance that deserves to be challenged" (789). Meanwhile, despite adopting this mantle of rescue, Western women frequently "overstepped indigenous women's subject position and sense of agency" (Syed and Ali 352). Western feminists often overlooked the impact of contextual factors on Third-World women.

The portrayal and understanding of Third-World women have largely been shaped by a Western feminist lens, often disregarding the influence of local customs, culture, history, language, education, traditions, family, society, religion, race and class, polity, and economy. This simplified view reduces Third-World women to a singular, homogenous entity, assuming that they share the same struggles and aspirations as their Western counterparts. Moreover, it presumes that all women possess the same capacity and strength to combat patriarchal systems and male-dominated cultures in which they live (Mahmoud and Sarhan, 2011, 35).
