The Job Posting:
Middle School Digital Media & Design Teacher
Annie Wright Schools seek a Middle School Digital Media & Design Teacher to begin on August 18, 2023. This is a full-time position and reports directly to the Middle School Director.

Mission Statement
Annie Wright’s strong community cultivates individual learners to become well-educated, creative, and responsible citizens for a global society.

About AWS
Tradition meets innovation at Annie Wright Schools, where we honor our rich history and traditions, embrace the present, and continue always to move forward. Founded in 1884, Annie Wright Schools serve students from age three through high school. The Lower and Middle Schools offer co-ed programs in Preschool through Grade 8, while separate Upper Schools for boys and girls offer day and boarding options in Grades 9 through 12, welcoming students from Tacoma and around the world. We are proud to be an International Baccalaureate World School, delivering IB programs in every division.

Position Description
The Middle School Digital Media & Design teacher is passionate about what they do and who they teach. They recognize and appreciate that the Design process and the creative process of the Arts go hand-in-hand. 

In Digital Media, the ideal candidate has the knowledge and enthusiasm to bring digital technology to life for our students through inquiry and discovery of the artistic process. This exploration into the concepts of change, communication, aesthetics, and identity could take the form of synthesized music, animation, digital art, videography, photography, or a wide spectrum of other artistic platforms that use digital media. This is a new course and, thus, the specifics of the units taught can fit the interests, talents, and passions of the teacher. Our one-to-one MacBook program means our students are equipped with a powerful tool to explore their creative world. In addition, they will have exposure to more classical visual art and theater classes to support growth in this course. Experience with applications from Adobe Creative Cloud is expected. 

The Design course at AWS is based around a maker space filled with duct tape, glue guns, and cardboard. With access to a woodshop, textiles lab, 3-D printers, and other tools, the ideal candidate allows students to creatively solve problems in a hands-on manner through human-centered, empathy-focused problem solving. All projects follow the IB MYP Design Cycle which encourages students to inquire and analyze, develop ideas, create a solution, and evaluate both their process and end product. For example, students may be tasked with designing a cardboard arcade game to appeal to a Grade 3 audience. They start by interviewing Grade 3 students, build a game, test it with a Grade 3 audience, make adjustments as needed, and evaluate the success of the process. As the facilitator of this course, no prior experience in the subject is required. However, enthusiasm for inquiry, the ability to guide students in a creative brainstorming process, and a passion for hands-on exploration are all essential qualities of a successful teacher of this course. Our students document their journey through both Digital Media and Design using Adobe Express and record their thoughts and progress in both courses over the three years of Middle School. 

Strong positive relationships and effective community-building are essential in Middle School; therefore, the Middle School Digital Media & Design Teacher must connect with young adolescents of all backgrounds and abilities to enable them to explore the world from multiple perspectives with eagerness and drive. Compassion and an understanding of the needs of this age group are vital to simultaneously support each student's academic and social-emotional growth and hold them accountable for their actions and choices. 

While energy, patience, and a little bit of goofiness are key elements that are indispensable for this position, the Middle School Digital Media & Design Teacher is also a team player who thrives in collaborative endeavors, both as an advisor and as a subject specialist in the Arts and Design departments. The creation and implementation of interdisciplinary units of inquiry that captivate, inform, and stretch our students are also essential components of the Middle Years Programme. While experience with the International Baccalaureate (IB) is not a prerequisite, an appreciation of criterion-based grading and a global, holistic approach to the IB is important. 

Position Overview: Core Duties & Responsibilities
The Middle School Digital Media & Design Teacher: 
teaches in alignment with the mission and philosophy of Annie Wright Schools and with the International Baccalaureate framework; 
designs and teaches Digital Media & Design with an emphasis on collaboration with the other Art (theater and visual arts) and Design teachers
collaborates with other faculty, including the Director of Middle School, student Advisors, the Middle School Counselor, and other colleagues to develop programming;
participates in collaborative planning and faculty meetings, serves as a Middle School Advisor, and fulfills other duties as assigned.
Qualifications
The Middle School Digital Media & Design Teacher will demonstrate key elements of the listed expertise and experiences. This is an aspirational list, and Annie Wright Schools encourages candidates to apply who may not currently possess but who are working on building all of these qualities. The Middle School Digital Media & Design Teacher: 
holds a BA in Art, Music, Design, Education, or a related field;
is familiar with independent schools and/or the International Baccalaureate framework;
demonstrates success as a teacher at the Middle School level and an interest in interdisciplinary curriculum development;
demonstrates enthusiasm for working with Middle School-aged students and the ability to form authentic relationships with them; 
demonstrates proficiency in educational technologies, specifically with Adobe Suite/Creative Cloud;
is a strong communicator and empathetic listener;
is innovative;
is organized and flexible;
practices cultural humility in personal interactions;
is eligible to work in the United States. (Note: Under our current employment policies, we are unable to sponsor work visas and do not offer positions to candidates who are not yet eligible to work in the United States.)

Rainforests are characterized by a warm and wet climate, with little variation in temperature throughout the year. Daytime temperatures in lowland tropical rainforests usually hover around 30-32°C (86-90°F), while nighttime temperatures rarely drop below 20°C (68°F). There is often a high level of humidity due to the constant evaporation and condensation of water, creating a damp and muggy environment.

Subject: Application for Veterinary Doctor Position at Groupe Westc

Dear [Hiring Manager's Name],

I am writing to express my strong interest in joining Groupe Westc as a Veterinary Doctor. I learned about your company's involvement in the Critical Worker Pilot program in the province of New Brunswick and admired the dedication to the development of poultry farming and the support for bringing qualified professionals from abroad. As an experienced veterinary doctor with a passion for animal health and production, I believe I would make a valuable contribution to your company.

With more than 20 years of experience in various areas of animal production, I am well-equipped to support the growth of your company across different facets of poultry farming. I hold a Veterinary Doctor degree from Venezuela and a Master's degree in Educational Technology. Growing up in a family of Veterinary Doctors and being actively involved in my father's farm operations have reinforced my passion for animal health, agricultural safety, and environmentally sustainable practices.

My areas of expertise include meat processing, preparation of sausages and smoked foods, artificial insemination of cows and pigs, management of broiler chickens, increasing reproductive efficiency in farms, and reducing mortality in newborn calves and abortions in dairy cows. I am confident that my skills and experience can contribute positively to Groupe Westc's operations.

I am excited about the opportunity to join your company and the Critical Worker Pilot of New Brunswick, and I am eager to use my knowledge and experience to support Groupe Westc's growth and success. Job Posting:
Full Job Description
Video Content Creator (Remote, Contractor)

The Art of Education University is seeking exceptional educators to produce video content for its YouTube channel, which has over 8,000 subscribers. Video Content Creators submit written proposals and scripts, along with corresponding video content for a predetermined amount of episodes. Video Content Creators must have K-12 art experience, strong writing and communication skills, confident camera presence, technology proficiency, enthusiasm and knowledge of trends and best practices in art education, and the ability to adhere to strict deadlines.

POSITION DETAILS
Structured as a remote part-time, project-based, contractor position. This position will report to the Media Content Manager

This position is eligible to remote work from the following locations: USA.

We have been a 100% remote company since the beginning!
MISSION
We grow amazing teachers by providing rigorous, relevant, and engaging professional development at every stage of their career.

The Details
ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS
Submit written proposals and scripts, along with corresponding video content for a predetermined amount of episodes, to be published on The Art of Education University’s YouTube Channel.
Create one Instagram Story per episode to highlight each episode they have created.
Provide timely and clear communication with the Media Content Manager.
KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES
Strong writing and communication skills.

Confident, natural, and engaging camera presence.

Ability to connect with a wide audience.

Excellent collaborator open to suggestions and feedback.

Knowledgeable of up-to-date trends and best practices in art education.

Passionate for sharing ideas with others.

Organized and able to meet deadlines.

Comfortable and proficient with technology and filming.

Position Requirements
While we have identified specific requirements for this role, we acknowledge that not all candidates may possess every requirement listed. We encourage applicants who believe they possess the necessary skills and experience to apply, regardless of whether they meet each requirement to the fullest extent.

EXPERIENCE
K-12 art classroom teaching experience.

OTHER REQUIREMENTS

Ability to view computer screens for significant periods of time. The Art of Education University is an online university therefore 95-98% of one’s time will be on or using technology.

Ability to use a laptop keyboard with accuracy.

Ability to hear at normal levels and through electronic devices such as laptops, earbuds, phones, and the like.

Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform essential functions.

Compensation
Video Content Creators earn a base stipend per episode once the commitment has been met (all filming is submitted and accepted and all Instagram stories are received).

We look forward to reviewing your application! Thank you for your interest in opportunities with AOEU.

Please contact <PRESIDIO_ANONYMIZED_EMAIL_ADDRESS> with any questions.

The Art of Education University is committed to providing equal employment opportunities for all employees and all applicants for employment. The Art of Education University will not discriminate against employees or applicants on the basis of actual or perceived age, race, color, national origin/ethnicity, ancestry, religion, sex, pregnancy (including childbirth, lactation, and related conditions), physical or mental disability, genetic information (including testing and characteristics), veteran status, uniformed service member status, or any other status protected by federal, state, or local laws. Job Posting:
Full Job Description
Gloo was founded as a mission-driven organization with the goal to release the passion in every person to Champion the growth of another so they can be all they were born to be.

Today, organizations of all sizes in the faith space use Gloo’s products to become more informed, better connected, and fully equipped to overcome their greatest challenges and achieve powerful outcomes, helping people progress through their personal growth journeys.

By building a common platform, we are creating a shared infrastructure that removes friction, promotes collaboration, and equips leaders with the right tools to galvanize personal growth and change lives. We are a fast-moving and passionate team that is looking for more talented professionals who are driven to make a positive impact.

The Opportunity:
As the newest member of our team you'll be helping us develop and perpetuate the Gloo brand through video storytelling. You’ll work closely with our corporate marketing team and cross-team stakeholders to bring the Gloo story and our platform utility to life for our core customers. Your experience conceptualizing and executing imaginative, future-forward, yet accessible video all using your own innovation and skillset is the secret to your success. You'll be telling stories and teaching viewers through video in both the tech and faith categories, so leveraging any tech and faith experience background will help you convey compelling stories.

The Team:
Our corporate marketing team is passionate about building a stable brand narrative and equipping our people and the ecosystem to tell Gloo’s story well. Our team members are drivers-moving swiftly into action in response to market and team needs, and are personable, innovative, and aspire to live out Gloo’s mission. The culture of our team is extremely important to us. We want you to be engaged in your projects, we want you to voice your ideas, and we want you to be proud of your accomplishments toward our shared company goals.
What You'll Be Doing:
Collaborating with the corporate marketing team and cross-team stakeholders to develop and execute video concepts that align with our brand messaging and business objectives
Edit and produce videos from raw footage, adding visual effects, sound design, and other elements needed to enhance the quality and impact of your videos
Develop, maintain, and manage production timelines-from pre-production to post production, delivering high-quality videos on-brand and on-time
Optimize video content for our variety of platforms - from the Gloo platform to social media, websites, mobile, events, zoom, and more
Stay up to date with industry trends and best practices, continually improving your skills in editing and up-leveling in areas like animation and sound design.
What We're Looking For:
A Bachelor's Degree (BA/BS) in Video Production, Film, Video Communications-commensurate experience may substitute for degree requirements
A minimum of 3 years of experience in an agency or video production organization
Expert proficiency in video editing software. Adobe Premier is Required
Experience in color grading is Required
Experience in motion graphics required, visual effects experience is a bonus!
Strong project management skills, with the ability to manage multiple projects simultaneously and deliver high-quality work within tight deadlines
Advanced level competency with Google Suite
An intense curiosity for how storytelling and educational content can serve the learning journey
A deep commitment to delighting your customers
Excellent communication skills with the ability to collaborate effectively with cross functional teams and inputs from stakeholders
Ability to empathize with and successfully integrate constructive feedback
Ability to deliver meaning and intent in video, sound, writing and in your personal communication skills
A positive and energetic demeanor with the flexibility to work with ambiguity and emerging strategic explorations

Compensation: $55,000 - $70,000
Our Team Members Enjoy:
Compensation and bonus commensurate with experience
Plenty of time off to keep you balanced
Medical benefits with multiple plan offerings, HSA contribution, and Dental and Vision plans
A dynamic, talented team, dedicated to changing the world and building an incredible business
Onsite and virtual social events to keep us connected in our hybrid work environment
Beautiful office space in downtown Boulder on Pearl Street, steps from coffee shops and blocks from hiking trails
Applicants offered employment will be required to provide evidence of authorization to work in the United States, and will be required to work from a physical location within the United States in accordance with Gloo’s Remote Work Policies.

A 10 lbm metal ball has a temperature of 200° F when it is placed in a 50 lbm
bath of water at room temperature (72° F). Heat transfer occurs between the two
substances until equilibrium is reached. Find this equilibrium temperature.

To find the equilibrium temperature, we'll use the concept of energy conservation. We assume that the heat gained by the water is equal to the heat lost by the metal ball.

First, let's convert the temperatures from degrees Fahrenheit to degrees Celsius:
Metal ball temperature: (200 - 32) * (5/9) ≈ 93.3°C
Water temperature: (72 - 32) * (5/9) ≈ 22.2°C

Let's denote the equilibrium temperature as T (in Celsius). We'll use the specific heat capacities (Cp) of the metal ball and water, which are given by:
Cp_water = 4.186 kJ/kg°C (for water)
Cp_metal = Cp_metal_ball (we didn't get the type of metal, so let's leave it as a variable)

Now let's apply the energy balance equation:

Heat gained by water = Heat lost by metal ball
(m_water * Cp_water * (T - T_water)) = (m_metal * Cp_metal * (T_metal - T))

Inserting the given values:
(50 kg * 4.186 kJ/kg°C * (T - 22.2°C)) = (4.535 kg * Cp_metal * (93.3°C - T))

To find T, we need to know the value of Cp_metal. If you provide the metal type, I can then solve for the equilibrium temperature T.

A 10 lbm metal ball has a temperature of 200° F when it is placed in a 50 lbm
bath of water at room temperature (72° F). Heat transfer occurs between the two
substances until equilibrium is reached. Find this equilibrium temperature.

To find the equilibrium temperature, we first need to convert the given masses from lbm (pound-mass) to kg (kilograms) and temperatures from degrees Fahrenheit to degrees Celsius.

Mass conversions:
10 lbm = 10 * 0.453592 = 4.536 kg
50 lbm = 50 * 0.453592 = 22.68 kg

Temperature conversions:
Metal ball temperature: (200 - 32) * (5/9) ≈ 93.3°C
Water temperature: (72 - 32) * (5/9) ≈ 22.2°C

Next, let's denote the equilibrium temperature as T (in Celsius). We'll use the specific heat capacities (Cp) of water and assume that the metal ball is made of steel.
Cp_water = 4.186 kJ/kg°C (for water)
Cp_steel = 0.49 kJ/kg°C (for steel)

Apply the energy balance equation (heat gained by water = heat lost by metal ball):

m_water * Cp_water * (T - T_water) = m_metal * Cp_metal * (T_metal - T)

Inserting the values and solving for T:

(22.68 kg * 4.186 kJ/kg°C * (T - 22.2°C)) = (4.536 kg * 0.49 kJ/kg°C * (93.3°C - T))

95.134 * (T - 22.2) = 2.222 * (93.3 - T)

By multiplying both sides:

95.134T - 2111.98 ≈ 207.065 - 2.222T

Combining like terms:

97.356T ≈ 2318.045

Now find T:

T ≈ 23.8°C

Now to convert back to Fahrenheit:

T_F ≈ (23.8 * (9/5)) + 32 ≈ 74.84°F

Therefore, the equilibrium temperature is about 74.84°F.

This is the Job Description:  Operations Manager
F45 Training Burleigh Heads
Burleigh Heads, Gold Coast QLD
Fitness & Personal Training (Sport & Recreation)
Full time
$65,000 – $75,000 per year
Posted 2d ago
More jobs from this company
CULTURE THAT CRUSHES IT

Our mission at F45 is to create the world’s greatest workout. This isn’t only about creating an unbelievable fitness experience—it’s about building a community and culture.

 

We are seeking a superstar Operations Manager to join our beautiful Burleigh Heads Studio: 
 

Benefits:

Flexible working schedule
Competitive salary and bonus structure
Virtual Assistant provided
Active ownership group
One of the largest F45 Studios in Australia.
 

Key Responsibilities:

Create, manage and exceed, all Sales and Operational budgets & goals
Drive financial plans and increase gross margins of the business through optimal programming and capacity utilization
Ensure all systems and studio practices/processes are adhered to.
Ensure a consistent sales effort is maintained at all times by providing daily sales goals and contests/incentive-based motivation, including establishing, expanding, and tracking outreach initiatives and strategic partnerships with local businesses, community groups, and charitable organizations
Recruit, hire, train and deliver the onboarding program for all staff
Maintain and grow the total membership base and oversee all aspects of the membership sales process
Increase studio conversion rate and achieve client retention goals
Drive client referral program
Maintain top-notch cleanliness, appearance, and organization of the studio and inventory
Demonstrate positive attitude and actions through a display of courtesy, service, cooperation, hospitality, sensitivity and professionalism to both clients and internal staff
Ensure studio branding by adhering to company guidelines and values
Maintain strong working knowledge of our small-group training programs.
Manage and oversee all day-to-day operations and overall studio performance. 
 

Qualifications:

Equivalent work experience, required
5+ years of proven sales leadership in the Health & Fitness industry required
Must have Personal Training Certification through a nationally recognized organization
Must have CPR/AED/First Aid Certification
3+ years of management experience, including directly overseeing all aspects of staff management from hiring, training, supporting, disciplining, and terminating
Must have outstanding experience delivering high-quality customer service, excellent communication, organizational, and written skills
Must possess excellent leadership and management skills to create a positive, successful environment for staff and clients
Ability to work independently and collaborate with Studio Owner, Sales Associates, and client
Highly organized with the ability to prioritize and meet deadlines
Computer proficiency with MS Office programs, MindBody Online, as well as various media platforms

is a 200 words cover letter brief

That depends on the specific requirements of the job application. In general, a cover letter should be concise and to the point while still demonstrating your qualifications and enthusiasm for the position. A length of 200 words can be appropriate for some job applications but may be too short for others.

If the job posting specifically mentions a word count or page limit for the cover letter, it is important to follow those guidelines. Otherwise, aim to convey your qualifications and interest in the position as effectively and efficiently as possible, using a length that feels appropriate for the job and your individual experience.

In any case, prioritize quality over quantity in your cover letter. It is better to have a shorter but well-written and personalized letter that effectively communicates your skills and enthusiasm than a longer, generic letter that fails to stand out.
it just says brief, do you think 200 is too long

If the job posting specifies a "brief" cover letter, it typically means that the employer expects a concise and focused letter. It is better to err on the side of being too short rather than too long for a brief cover letter. 

In this case, a cover letter that is 200 words long can be appropriate, as it shows that you are able to convey your skills and experience clearly and concisely. However, it's important to ensure that your letter is well-structured, highlights your relevant skills and achievements, and is tailored to the job requirements to make a strong impact.

conversation.content:
write a cover letter in response to this job posting:  Associate Consultant / Client Engagement Specialist

Wayfinding Partners is seeking a motivated, justice-driven associate consultant to join our growing team. This role is integral to the success of our client engagements and racial justice programs.

We’re seeking individuals who have strong project management skills, growing ease with facilitation, the ability to solve complex problems, and a knack for relationship-building.

This person must also have familiarity with the nonprofit and philanthropic sectors and has a nuanced understanding of how oppression operates at varying levels.

The ideal candidate has also demonstrated a commitment to and aptitude for each of the Wayfinding values: justice in action, empathy and connection, community and self care, emergence and magic, and the fractal nature of existence and change.

WORKING WITH WAYFINDING PARTNERS
The mission of Wayfinding Partners is to guide people, organizations, and communities on a journey of self-discovery, and build their capacity to design and thrive in change.

We partner with folks to learn from and reckon with history, heal in the present, and create a just, equitable, joy-filled future. Our philosophy is that by undoing the systems, structures and mindsets that perpetuate inequities, we make space for justice and liberation.

Wayfinding Partners is a completely remote team. We travel for team retreats and client engagements.

THE ROLE
The Associate Consultant reports to a Senior Consultant, and serves as a key support in the delivery of Wayfinding Partner’s consulting engagements and community initiatives. This Associate Consultant role works directly with organizations in the nonprofit, philanthropic, and public sectors, conducting organizational needs assessments, designing and implementing strategic interventions, and guiding organizational culture change. Associate Consultants also support, and in some cases facilitate, community programs.

We meet our clients where they are and customize our work according to their growth opportunities, readiness for change, and desired outcomes. As such, each client engagement looks slightly different. However, there are core opportunities and responsibilities unique to the Associate Consultant role.

RESPONSIBILITIES
Strategic Advising

Assist Senior Consultants in coordinating fieldwork by contributing to the development of project plans, scheduling and preparing for workshops and interviews, gathering documentation, and liaising with client staff
Survey and understand the external landscape or “ecosystem” in which clients conduct their work to identify opportunities and challenges
Assist Senior Consultants in assessing clients’ capacity—structures, culture, funding, racial equity lens—and guide clients’ approach to improve and strengthen their organizational systems and leadership
Actively partner with Senior Consultants to identify and articulate potential pathways for clients to consider to help maximize their impact and achieve their goals
Analysis and Storytelling

Review and analyze quantitative and qualitative data, including research reports, stakeholder interview notes, and background materials
Lead and actively participate in team meetings to discuss and develop findings and recommendations
Develop written reports and presentations summarizing analysis and recommendations
Design, Facilitation, and Holding Space

Work with Senior Consultants to design meetings, retreats, and events, including preparing internal and external agendas
Facilitate portions of client meetings, retreats, and small group sessions
Facilitate community events, including elements of signature workshops and cohort programs
Project Management

Work closely with Senior Consultants to maintain and update each project’s schedule of events, communicating any changes to the full consulting team and client throughout engagement
Build meaningful client relationships, through all interactions, and ensure they remain engaged in the project
Coordinate with consulting teams and the client to create and send calendar invites for engagements
Attend client meetings to take notes and assist in any facilitations
Ensure all documentation pertaining to each client is uploaded to the client folder on the shared drive
Create and maintain documents per client to track all engagement deliverables, ensuring activities and coaching hours align with client contract.
Support Senior Consultants in ensuring deliverables are completed in a timely manner, communicating any changes to the client.
Wayfinding Culture Curation and Care-Taking

Model Wayfinding values in action, paying particular attention to self- and community-care.
Uplift opportunities for the Wayfinding team to be in community with each other
Continuously brainstorm and make recommendations for how to make Wayfinding a liberated workplace
QUALIFICATIONS
We recognize that one candidate may not possess every desired qualification listed below. We also know that this list is not exhaustive of all the wonderful qualities that could make you successful in this role—we hope you share those with us in your cover letter. As we search for our next teammate, we are looking for the following:

Minimum of three (3) years of relevant full time professional experience in the nonprofit or philanthropic sectors. Experience in organization development, education, and/or nonprofit management is preferred.
Clear point of view on racial equity, social justice, liberation—and eagerness for ongoing growth, dialogue, and learning
Comfort, tenacity, and grace in developing relationships across culture, race, ethnicity, gender, sexual orientation, religion, ability, political affiliation, and other forms of difference
Comfort in giving and receiving positive and constructive feedback to colleagues and clients
Capacity to handle multiple tasks, remain flexible, prioritize appropriately, and manage workflow for oneself and others
Highly motivated self-starter with demonstrated comfort taking initiative, learning quickly, and working in virtual environments
Excitement in the recognition that we are learning all the time, and eagerness to use challenges as opportunities to gain new knowledge
Energy Transfer (i.e. Compensation)
In recognition and appreciation of team members’ partnership with Wayfinding and our clients, we offer salaries commensurate with experience and benefits that emphasize health, family, and wellness.

The salary range for the Associate Consultant position is $65,000 - $75,000. Our benefits package includes paid time off, wellness days, paid holidays, 401(k) retirement plans, health care reimbursement, long-term disability plans, along with other fun sprinkled throughout the year. Wayfinding Partners also closes for one week in summer and the last two weeks of the calendar year.

[Your Name]
[Your Address]
[City, State, ZIP]
[Email Address]
[Phone Number]
[Today’s Date]

[Wayfinding Partners Hiring Manager's Name]
Wayfinding Partners
[Company Address]
[City, State, ZIP]

Dear [Hiring Manager's Name],

I am writing to express my strong interest in the Associate Consultant / Client Engagement Specialist position at Wayfinding Partners, as advertised on your website. English
write a cover letter for applying for a post-doctoral position at MIT University in the transportation engineering department.

conversation.content:
Write a cover letter for applying for a post-doctoral position at MIT University in the transportation engineering department.
First, introduce me:
I was born in a small city, but I always had big dreams, and I want to change my world and the whole world to make it a better place to live. From years of my undergraduate education to now, I have always dreamed of enhancing my academic and personal qualifications by participating in international studies. So I choose Transportation engineering to make people's lives easier and safer by solving traffic problems and increasing traffic safety to create a better and safer world. I always do my best in my field. I get the Middle East Technical University Tuition Fee Exemption Scholarship award for four years, the Tubitak conference scholarship for two conferences, and a government scholarship for the top ten university students.
Second, introduce my master's education:
I want to explain my educational background and relative experiences up to this point.
After completing my undergraduate studies at Urmia University, department of civil engineering, in 2010, I applied for a master's degree at Middle East Technical University (Ankara, Turkey), also in Transportation engineering. During my master's degree, I took courses on various topics such as Transportation policy, Traffic Eng.1, City planning policy, Traffic psychology, urban design, and Travel demand modeling and forecasting. I wrote my thesis entitled 'Estimation of Traffic Impact at Signalized Intersections around the Proposed Health Campus in Etlik, Ankara, by Using PTV Vistro and Synchro Simulation Software' with the help of my thesis advisor Assoc. Prof. Dr. Hediye TuydesYaman. In my study, I have estimated the current and predicted the future level of service (LOS), traffic impact analysis (TIA), and Origin-Destination matrix for the project about the proposed health campus in Etlik, Ankara.
Third, introduce my Ph.D. education:
In the fall of 2017, I was admitted to the Transportation and Department of Middle East Technical University as a Ph.D. student. During the Ph. D., I strengthened my knowledge of public transport and computer science-based courses, which I intend to follow during my thesis studies. For my Ph.D. studies, I focused on the performance of public transit, GIS, R studio, and big data analysis. My thesis topic is estimating public transit performance based on smart card data. At the end of my thesis, I suggested a formula for the performance rate for public transit according to passenger number, attraction rate, and user perspective.
Fourth, introduce my work experience:
During my study, I worked as a research assistant and teaching assistant. Also, I have a great experience in PUYOL Engineering and consultancy company as a manager of transportation and traffic projects such as Sustainable Urban Mobility Plan (SUMP), traffic impact analysis, macro simulation, micro simulation, public transport planning, signal optimization, green wave, road safety audit, and feasibility projects.
Fifth, introduce my area of interest:
I have more than ten years of professional expertise in Transportation and Traffic engineering fields to design and analyze:
Intelligent Transportation systems (ITS), Intersection Design, Intersection Safety Analysis, Traffic Impact Analysis (TIA),
Traffic Optimization, Level of Service (LOS), Traffic Modelling, Traffic Simulation, Traffic Safety Analysis, Public Transportation System, Traffic Psychology, GIS, Spatial Analysis, Transportation planning and management, Urban Planning, Statistics, Big data analysis, Project Management, and Designing roadway traffic signs.
Moreover, I know five langue which helps me always find new opportunities in my carrier.
Sixth, introduce my references:
I would appreciate it if you considered me for the scholarship. I would also like to mention that my Professor (Prof.Dr. HEDİYE TÜYDEŞ YAMAN <PRESIDIO_ANONYMIZED_EMAIL_ADDRESS> ) and my co-advisor (Prof.Dr. Ela BABALIK SUTCLIFFE <PRESIDIO_ANONYMIZED_EMAIL_ADDRESS> ) can provide the recommendation letters.
Seventh, introduce motivation to apply:
This post-doc position at MIT University directly relates to my field of studies and fits with my experience. Participating in the Transportation Lab at MIT University will give me a great chance to learn about the research environment and experience there.
Eighth, wait to reply:
I am highly motivated to fulfill the program's requirements to the fullest, and I eagerly look forward to being a part of the MIT transportation department.
Many thanks for considering my request. Best Regards

[Your Full Name]

[Your Address]

[City, State, Zip Code]

[Your Email Address]

[Today's Date]

[Recipient's Full Name]

The Department of Transportation Engineering

MIT University

[Address]

[City, State, Zip Code]

Subject: Application for Post-Doctoral Position in the Department of Transportation Engineering

Dear [Recipient's Full Name],

I am writing to express my interest in applying for the Post-Doctoral Position in the Transportation Engineering Department at MIT University. Given my comprehensive academic background and professional experience, I believe I would make significant contributions to the esteemed department.

For over a decade, I have been dedicated to my field of study, and I am highly motivated to achieve excellence in transportation and traffic engineering. I am confident that a post-doctoral position with your esteemed institution will provide me with the research environment and diverse collaborations necessary for my professional growth.

My master's and Ph.D. degrees in Transportation Engineering from Middle East Technical University have equipped me with advanced knowledge and a deep understanding of essential concepts such as traffic modeling, intelligent transportation systems, and GIS applications in transportation engineering. My Ph.D. dissertation focused on public transit performance estimation using smart card data, allowing me to explore innovative solutions to real-world transportation problems.

Working as a research and teaching assistant in the Transportation Engineering Department at Middle East Technical University and as a manager of transportation and traffic projects at PUYOL Engineering and Consultancy has enriched my research and practical skills. I have valuable experience with ITS, Intersection Design, Traffic Optimization, Public Transport Planning, and more.

My motivation for applying for this post-doctoral position is fueled by the desire to be a part of the renowned research and learning environment at MIT University, allowing me to grow as an expert in my field. The position aligns with my professional interests and offers unique avenues to expand my horizons as a researcher and contribute to the advancements within the transportation engineering discipline.

I am excited to work with the distinguished faculty at MIT and contribute to the ongoing research projects in the Transportation Engineering Department. It would be an honor to collaborate with my colleagues and learn from their expertise, enabling me to make a tangible impact on the field.

Enclosed are my curriculum vitae and other supporting documents for your review. I kindly request you to consider my application for the post-doctoral position, and I eagerly await your response.

Thank you for taking the time to review my application, and I hope to hear from you soon.

Sincerely,

[Your Full Name]

conversations.facetValue: define what a reference is in the context of job applications.

allFacetValues.value: understand what a reference is in the context of applying for jobs.
English
define what a reference is in the context of job applications.

conversation.content: Pertaining to the topic of employers and applying to jobs, what is a "reference"?

A reference is a person who can vouch for a job applicant's suitability for a particular position. References are typically individuals who have worked with or know the applicant in a professional capacity and can speak to their work ethic, skills, and personal qualities. Employers often request references as part of the hiring process to validate an applicant's qualifications and assess their potential fit for the job.

Most recently I worked at Energy Profiles Limited where I worked on analytics and modelling for utilities data primarily working with SQL server and a C# application.

My experience with working with backend API’s and data would absolutely help me succeed at this role. In addition, I have a strong background in math and quantitative/statistical with a degree in applied mathematics and enjoy incrementally improving metrics.

After earning a degree in mathematics, I transitioned to a career in software development, completing a year in Computer Science at University of Toronto before accepting my first professional role as a Software Developer with Bank of Montreal. At BMO my work focused primarily on development of a web-based lending platform using a mix of Java and JavaScript with Oracle DB, in addition to data analytics/pipelining work and automation in Python. Most recently I worked at Energy Profiles Limited where I worked on analytics and modelling for utilities data.

As for the requirements of this role, I have a strong background in math and quantitative/statistical methods as well as programming in Python data science stack. I have experience developing features in a full stack environment and operating within a codebase with numerous external integrations. I understand the diligence required for producing software that handles financial data and the techniques for producing robust products (Testing APIs, SDLC etc.). I hold a BSc in Applied Mathematics and Finance from the University of Western Ontario and additional coursework in Computer Science at the University of Toronto.

I would welcome the opportunity to meet with you to learn more about the position at Tonal and discuss my credentials and ways that I might be a fit. Patient SG-04-001 procedure duration was 98 min that's huge compared to all the duration. A double-check could be helpful too. 

"

Additionally, there are several other patients within the dataset whose data appears to be inconsistent (please refer to the attached document). For example, Patient GR-01-001 had more than 450 ml of contrast media used during the procedure, and all of the device evaluation questions were answered with a rating of 5. I suspect that the user may have misunderstood the evaluation rules and mistakenly given the procedure a high rating due to its successful outcome and reasonable duration. 

Patient GR-02-001 had a vessel diameter measurement of 25 (mm???), while all of the other vessel diameters with the same access point were reported to be within 2 and 3.5 mm. It is possible that the unit of diameter was not reported consistently across different sites, so a double-check could be beneficial. 

In addition, Patient SG-04-001 had a significantly longer procedure duration of 98 minutes, in contrast to the typical duration for these procedures. It might be helpful to conduct a double-check to verify this abnormal duration.

I am writing to seek your valuable advice on a promising marketing opportunity that can effectively promote our geospatial services within the sustainability industry.

As you might notice, I have been keeping my efforts to promote our ERM geospatial offerings during the last year, regardless of being in Hong Kong or China mainland.
Most recently, one of my connections in the industry, an influential international media platform called Geospatial World (https://www.linkedin.com/company/geospatial-world/), widely recognized within the geospatial industry, reached out to me. Their premier bi-monthly magazine, Geospatial Tech, is preparing to launch their latest issue specially focused on Sustainability, Climate, and Blue Economy. This issue will be unveiled at the upcoming Geospatial World Forum in Rotterdam this May and will receive extensive coverage across social media channels such as Facebook, LinkedIn, and Twitter.

The theme of this publication is a perfect alignment with our ERM business, and I believe this presents a fantastic opportunity for international publicity.

In terms of cost, Geospatial World offers a comprehensive package comprising 3 pages of custom-made content and a 1-page advertisement for USD 3,500. They will collaborate with us, conducting interviews to help tailor the content, while providing us with the final approval authority. The deadline to finalize the content is April 20th, with the publication scheduled for mid-May.

Given our ongoing efforts to promote our Geospatial services, I am confident that this opportunity will greatly enhance our visibility and reach to potential clients. I would appreciate the chance to discuss this prospect further with you and gain insights from your extensive experience.

Thank you in advance for your time and consideration.

Kind regards,

conversations.facetValue: provide guidelines for writing professional emails, both formal and informal.

allFacetValues.value: receive guidance on making an email look professional, whether it is formal or informal.
English
provide guidelines for writing professional emails, both formal and informal.

conversation.content:
There are different ways to make a formal and informal email look professional, depending on the context and the relationship with the recipient. Here are some tips for making an email look professional in both formal and informal settings.

1. Use a clear and concise subject line: The subject line should clearly describe the content of the email so that the recipient knows what to expect. In a formal email, the subject line should be more specific, while in an informal email, it can be more casual but still informative.

2. Address the recipient properly: In a formal email, always use the recipient's full name and their title or professional designation (i.e., Dr., Mr., Ms., etc.). In an informal email, you can use the recipient's first name.

3. Begin with a proper salutation: For formal emails, begin with a formal salutation (i.e., Dear Dr. Smith,) and use the appropriate title. In an informal email, you can use a less formal salutation or simply the recipient's first name (i.e., Hi John,).

4. Use proper grammar and punctuation: Regardless of the email being formal or informal, always use proper grammar, punctuation, and spelling. Keep the email easy to read by avoiding long paragraphs and using bullet points or numbering when relevant.

5. Keep the tone professional: In a formal email, maintain a professional tone throughout the message, avoiding slang or informal language. In an informal email, you can maintain a more casual tone, but still focus on being clear, concise, and to the point.

6. Provide clear and relevant information: Make sure your email contains all the necessary information for the recipient to understand the purpose of the email and take any required action. Be as specific as possible and avoid unnecessary details.

7. End with a polite closing: In a formal email, use a formal closing (i.e., Sincerely, Kind regards, etc.) and include your full name, title, and contact information if appropriate. In an informal email, a less formal closing (i.e., Best, Cheers, etc.) can be used, along with your first name.

8. Proofread your email: Before sending your email, it's important to proofread it for any grammatical errors or typos. This helps to ensure that your message is clear and professional.

By following these guidelines, your email will look professional regardless of whether it is a formal or informal communication.

conversations.facetValue: provide guidance on best practices for writing clear and professional business emails.

allFacetValues.value: provide guidance on best practices for writing effective business emails.
English
provide guidance on best practices for writing clear and professional business emails.

conversation.content:
1. Keep it simple - A good business email should be concise and to the point. Avoid using complex sentence structures and use clear language. This will make it easy for the recipient to understand what you are trying to achieve and will encourage them to respond.

2. Use a clear subject line - Make sure the subject line accurately reflects the content of your email. This will help the recipient to prioritise your email and will increase the likelihood of a prompt response.

3. Use a professional email address - Whenever possible, use your company email address when sending business emails. This helps to establish credibility and trust between you and the recipient.

4. Use a proper salutation and closing - Start your email with a professional greeting, such as "Dear Mr./Ms. [last name]" or "Hello [first name]". Close your email with a polite sign-off, like "Best regards" or "Sincerely".

5. Use proper formatting - Make sure your email is properly formatted, with paragraphs and line breaks, so it's easy to read. Additionally, use standard fonts and font sizes.

6. Be polite and respectful - Always maintain a polite and respectful tone in your emails. Even if you are frustrated or annoyed, it's important to remain professional in your communications.

7. Proofread and spell-check - Always proofread your emails for spelling, grammar, and punctuation errors. Use a spell-check tool if necessary. This will help to ensure that your message is professional and easy to read.

8. Include contact information - Make sure to include your contact information in your email signature. This will make it easy for the recipient to get in touch with you if they have any questions or concerns.

9. Use bullet points or numbered lists - If your email contains multiple points or requests, use bullet points or numbered lists to make it easier for the recipient to understand and respond to each item.

10. Respond promptly - Respond to emails as quickly as possible, ideally within 24 hours. A prompt response shows that you are attentive and respectful of the recipient's time.

how to calculate salary hike

The calculation of salary hike usually depends on several factors, such as company policies, employee performance, inflation, industry trends, etc. However, a basic formula to calculate salary hike is as follows:

Salary hike = (Current salary x percentage increase)/100

For example, if the current salary of an employee is $60,000, and the company policy allows a 5% salary hike, the calculation would be as follows:

Salary hike = (60,000 x 5)/100 = $3,000

Therefore, the employee's new salary would be $63,000 after the 5% salary hike.

Keep in mind that this is just a basic formula, and several other factors may influence the actual calculation of salary hike. It's always best to check with your employer or HR department to get a more accurate idea of how salary hikes are calculated at your workplace.
what is 39% of 5 lakh 20 thousand rupees

39% of 5 lakh 20 thousand rupees can be calculated as follows:

39% = 39/100 = 0.39

5 lakh 20 thousand rupees = 520000

Now, multiply 0.39 with 520000 to get the result:

39% of 5 lakh 20 thousand rupees = 0.39 x 520000 = Rs. 202,800

Therefore, 39% of 5 lakh 20 thousand rupees is Rs. 202,800.

1652000 - 1400000 = 252000

Therefore, the result of the subtraction 1652000 - 1400000 is 252000.
1400000 + 252000 is what percentage to increment to 14lpa?

To calculate the percentage increment needed to reach a salary of 14 LPA (14 lakh per annum) from a current salary of 1400000 + 252000 = 1652000, we can use the following formula:

Percentage increment = ((New Salary - Current Salary) / Current Salary) x 100

Here, the "New Salary" is 14 LPA or 1400000, and the "Current Salary" is 1652000. 

Plugging in these values, we get:

Percentage increment = ((1400000 - 1652000) / 1652000) x 100

Percentage increment = (-252000 / 1652000) x 100

Percentage increment = -0.1528 x 100

Percentage increment = -15.28%

Therefore, a decrease of 15.28% in the current salary of 1652000 is needed to reach a salary of 14 LPA. Alternatively, an increment of 15.28% in a salary of 1400000 is required to reach the desired salary of 14 LPA.

Informed by the pioneering theories of Freud and other psychologists, writers such as Henry James, and D. H. For these authors, the rising field of psychology offered not only a new lens through which to interrogate the intricacies of human behavior, but also a powerful artistic tool to craft innovative narrative methods, styles, and techniques. conversation.content:
I am writing a new paper, and want you to act as an academic journal editor. Please rephrase the paragraph of new paper from an academic angle:"Through statistics on the simulated dataset, different K and their corresponding Kth are determined, as shown in Table 1. The average variance of the clustering results for the parameter combination of θ, K and Kth is shown in Figure 3.
The spatio-temporal clustering produced by the OSCAR includes clustering results corresponding to different θ values, illustrated in Figures 4. Comparisons reveal that all θ values accurately identify the evolution processes of development and disappearance (process A) and merging and splitting (process C). Nevertheless, for the moving evolution process (process B), results differ substantially based on θ values. When θ is 0.25, event C at each timestampttamp can be effectively recognized. Conversely, with θ set at 0.5, the moving evolution process (B) is insufficiently identified, resulting in discontinuous spatio-temporal clusters. At timestampttamp 3 and 7, process B is divided into three spatio-temporal clusters: clusters 4, 6, and 7. The speed of process B around timestampt 3 and 7 is fast, causing lower overlapping degrees of snapshot objects at subsequent timestampt. That leads to interruption of the cluster expansion in time dimensions and the emergence of new clusters. With θ at 0.75, the process B is only detected when movement is comparatively slow (during timestampt 5 to 7), that is worse than when θ is 0.5. 
For rapidly moving evolution processes, an increase in speed coincides with a decrease in the overlapping area of snapshot objects at adjacent timestampt. Thus, it is necessary to set a lower value of θ for the fast-moving evolution process. The faster the moving speed, the lower the value of parameter θ should be.
"

Utilizing statistical analyses on a simulated dataset, varying K values and their corresponding Kth were ascertained, which are presented in Table 1. The clustering results' average variance for the combined parameters of θ, K, and Kth is depicted in Figure 3. 

The spatio-temporal clustering generated by the OSCAR encompasses clustering outcomes correlated with distinct θ values, as demonstrated in Figure 4. Upon comparison, it was observed that all θ values precisely determine the developmental and cessation evolution processes (process A), as well as the merging and splitting evolution processes (process C). However, for the movement-based evolution process (process B), the outcomes vary significantly depending on the θ values. When θ is set at 0.25, event C can be effectively discerned at each timestamp. On the other hand, when θ is designated as 0.5, the movement-based evolution process (process B) is inadequately identified, culminating in discontinuous spatio-temporal clusters. At timestamps 3 and 7, process B is segregated into three spatio-temporal clusters: clusters 4, 6, and 7. The velocity of process B around timestamps 3 and 7 is rapid, resulting in reduced overlapping degrees of snapshot objects at subsequent timestamps. This subsequently leads to disruptions in cluster expansion within the temporal dimensions and the emergence of new clusters. With θ set at 0.75, process B is detectable solely when the movement is relatively slow (during timestamps 5 to 7), rendering it less effective than when θ is 0.5.

For accelerated movement-based evolution processes, an increase in speed corresponds to a diminishing overlapping area of snapshot objects at adjacent timestamps. Consequently, it is crucial to designate a lower θ value for fast-moving evolution processes. The higher the movement speed, the lower the assigned value of parameter θ should be.

conversation.content: Расскажи про пунктуацию в стиле драгонфорс

Как и в любом другом тексте, в стиле драгонфорс использование правильной пунктуации является важным элементом создания читабельного и понятного текста. Вот некоторые особенности пунктуации, которые могут встречаться в стиле драгонфорс:

1. Диалог. В драгонфорсе диалоги пишутся с использованием кавычек. Так же важно не забывать о знаках препинания в диалогах, таких как запятые, точки и тире.

Пример: "Привет, - сказал дракон. - Как ты поживаешь?"

2. Восклицательные знаки. В драгонфорсе часто используются восклицательные знаки, так как они помогают передать эмоциональность и интенсивность.

Пример: "Мы должны победить! Иначе наш мир погибнет!"

3. Тире. Тире используются в драгонфорсе для обозначения длительной паузы, недодуманности, перехода к другой мысли или изменения темы.

Пример: "Я сомневаюсь... Так ли это было на самом деле?"

4. Интерьерные монологи. В драгонфорсе часто встречаются интерьерные монологи, в которых герой высказывает свои мысли вслух. В таких случаях использование кавычек не требуется, зато необходимо использовать знаки препинания, чтобы читатель мог понимать, где заканчивается речь и начинается мысль.

Пример: Я должен был бы подумать об этом заранее. Зачем я так поступил?

5. Запятые. Запятые в драгонфорсе используются для обозначения перечисления, сложноподчиненных и простых предложений.

Пример: "Он был высоким, сильным и очень красивым, но был грубым и невежливым по отношению к другим людям".

Таким образом, пунктуация в стиле драгонфорс играет важную роль в создании правильного ритма, эмоций и понимания текста. Будьте внимательны и аккуратны в использовании правильной пунктуации, чтобы захватить своего читателя в мир драгонфорса.

conversation.content: 请问这句话的主谓宾是什么？怎么看？            The article raises important questions about the social and environmental consequences of unchecked economic growth and calls for more sustainable and equitable approaches to development.

主语：The article
谓语：raises
宾语：important questions about the social and environmental consequences of unchecked economic growth and calls for more sustainable and equitable approaches to development. 

可以看出，文章主题是"raises"所列举的问题和呼吁，因此这个句子的主谓宾为The article raises important questions about the social and environmental consequences of unchecked economic growth and calls for more sustainable and equitable approaches to development.
这句话的主句和从句是什么

这句话没有明显的主句和从句的分别。它是一个完整的句子，具有一个主语、一个谓语和一个宾语，同时还包含一个关于"the social and environmental consequences of unchecked economic growth"的形容词短语和一个关于"development"的名词短语。整个句子表达了文章对于经济增长所带来的社会和环境影响的担忧以及对于可持续和公正发展的呼吁。
那这句话的被动形式是什么？

句子的被动形式为："Important questions about the social and environmental consequences of unchecked economic growth are raised by the article, and more sustainable and equitable approaches to development are called for."
把这句话改写为几个简单句的结合

可以将这个复杂句子改写为两个简单句子结合在一起：

1. The article raises important questions about the social and environmental consequences of unchecked economic growth.
2. The article calls for more sustainable and equitable approaches to development.
使用复杂和学术的词汇改写以上句子

1. The article posits significant inquiries regarding the socio-environmental outcomes of unbridled economic expansion. 
2. The article advocates for the adoption of more sustainable and equitable methodologies when advancing developmental pursuits.

使用复杂和学术的词汇改写该句子：          The article raises important questions about the social and environmental consequences of unchecked economic growth and calls for more sustainable and equitable approaches to development.

The article elucidates crucial inquiries concerning the ramifications of uncontrolled economic expansion on the socio-environmental framework while simultaneously demanding the implementation of more sustainable and impartial strategies to spur development.

This approach skillfully circumvents the restrictions imposed by conventional third-person omniscient narration, enabling authors to delve more profoundly into the essence of the child's character and to investigate their deepest fears, aspirations, and fantasies with an unparalleled level of intimacy and immediacy.

The groundbreaking novel by Mark Twain marks a critical turning point in the progression of narrative literature, as it demonstrates the potency of utilizing a child's perspective to examine the multifaceted social, cultural, and moral dimensions of a given milieu. Postdating this influential work, the literary landscape has seen an array of texts featuring young narrators, each elucidating unique nuances and thematic preoccupations. From the enthralling Romantic fairy tales to the more earthbound Victorian realist narratives, the advent of psychology as a research field in the early twentieth century profoundly enriched the understanding and sophistication of child-centric narratives.

By drawing on the pioneering theories of Freud and his contemporaries, writers such as Henry James and D.H. Lawrence endeavored to reveal new aspects of the human experience through a deeper examination of the primary human instincts, repressed memories, and inner emotional conflicts that determine human behavior. The emergence of psychology as a discipline signified a watershed moment for authors of child-centric narratives, as it offered them unprecedented access to the child's inner world. Consequently, psychology not only affords a new lens to interrogate the intricacies of human behavior but also functions as an influential artistic tool to develop innovative narrative forms, methodologies, and styles.

A salient development in this field is the increasing emphasis on the internal landscape of the child—the complex interweaving of thoughts, emotions, and sensory perceptions that cultivate a young protagonist's emerging self-awareness and identity. This approach adeptly circumvents the limitations of traditional third-person omniscient narration, allowing authors to delve more deeply into the core of the child's being and to explore their most intimate fears, aspirations, and reveries with an unparalleled level of immediacy and intimacy.

Eurocentrism is generally defined as a way of thinking that places European culture, history, and values at the center of the world while ignoring or downplaying the contributions of other cultures and civilizations. One could argue that Europe, more specifically Western Europe or “the West,” is often used as a universal symbol that presupposes the superiority of European cultural values over those of non-European societies. Eurocentric narratives have a recurring inclination to overlook and undervalue the contributions of non-Western cultures. Such accounts distort non-European histories and legacies by viewing them solely through European or western perspectives. This perspective has created a false dichotomy between the West and the non- European societies, perpetuating the notion that the West is superior and in control of all areas of life, including social, political, cultural, scientific, military, and economic fields. Such thinking has led to the use of derogatory terms to describe the “non-west,” fostering the idea that the non-west is inferior, illogical, aggressive, alien, fanatical, and barbaric in comparison to West. This belief in Western superiority is often reinforced through various forms of discourse, including history, literature, art, music, etc. In a similar vein, through the utilization of Eurocentric and imperialistic perspectives, academic discourse has consistently depicted ‘Eastern societies’ as exotic and racialized, perpetuating a biased portrayal of the Orient or East. In his seminal text Orientalism (1979), Edward Said, a Palestinian critic, asserts that “European culture gained in strength and identity by setting itself off against the Orient as a sort of surrogate and even underground self.” (3) This dichotomy between the West and the East often presents the West as a modern, flowing territory and the East as a static, archaic region. Therefore, the Orient functions as a mirror to the West in that the West relies heavily on its counterpart, the Orient, for its own sense of superiority. (Sandy and Ouardi, 2019, p. 129) On the other hand, this discourse of exoticism, essentialism, and stereotyping of the East and its people has been used to justify colonization, exploitation, and violence against Eastern civilizations.
The Knowledge production or the representation of the Orient in Western narratives is not a recent development; it has existed since the earliest times. Edward Said traces the development of this discourse back to ancient Greece, using two plays by Aeschylus as references. He reiterates that Asia in the play The Persians is portrayed as a ‘hostile other,’ a ‘world beyond the seas.’ In fact, colonists exploited literary works as propaganda weapons from the beginning to spread false images of the Orient.  According to Said, 
The “Orient was created -or, as I call it, “Orientalized”- and to believe that such things happen simply as a necessity of the imagination is to be disingenuous… The Orient was Orientalized not only because it was discovered to be “Oriental” in all those ways considered commonplace by an average nineteenth-century European, but also because it could be -that is, submitted to being- made Oriental.” (5-6)
Said’s argument centers on the idea that the West’s portrayal of the Orient is heavily biased and serves to further its own dominance. Additionally, this euphoria of the West’s supremacy over the East is characterised by a tremendous power disparity, according to Said. He notes that the power imbalance between the West and the Orient allows for the creation of such universalized images that further reinforce this dominance. This power allows the West to shape how the Orient is perceived and represented and to create narratives that serve its interests. However, Said’s analysis does not explicitly address gender as a factor in constructing these narratives. This paper aims to build upon Said’s argument by examining the role of gender in how European discourse has portrayed women in colonized societies, specifically how the idea of rescuing and civilizing these women was used to justify and reinforce imperial power. By considering the intersection of gender and imperialism, this paper seeks to provide a more nuanced and comprehensive understanding of the way that Western narratives have shaped and continue to shape the perception of the Orient.

This paradigm, therefore, not only consolidates the stature of the West, but also perpetuates the subordination of non-European societies within global power structures, and the spheres of knowledge and influence. Eurocentrism and Binary Opposites: East vs. West

Eurocentrism embodies an epistemological framework that positions European culture, history, and values as the global axis, simultaneously marginalizing or diminishing non-European contributions. This ethnocentric stance envisions the West as a model of universal values and cultural supremacy, engendering a systematic depreciation and misrepresentation of non-European cultures. As a result, Eurocentric discourse fosters a false binary between the West and non-European societies, perpetuating notions of Western superiority and dominion across various domains, such as social, political, cultural, scientific, military, and economic realms. Pejorative labels ascribed to the "non-West" reinforce connotations of inferiority, irrationality, belligerence, otherness, fanaticism, and barbarism.

This paradigm not only bolsters the West's stature but also sustains the subjugation of non-European societies within global power hierarchies and knowledge spheres. Western superiority is often underscored through diverse forms of discourse, encompassing history, literature, art, music, and more. Similarly, employing Eurocentric and imperialistic viewpoints, academic discourse persistently portrays 'Eastern societies' as exotic and racialized, perpetuating a skewed depiction of the Orient. In Orientalism (1979), Edward Said contends that "European culture gained in strength and identity by setting itself off against the Orient as a sort of surrogate and even underground self" (3). This binary opposition often represents the West as modern and fluid while depicting the East as static and archaic.

Thus, the Orient serves as a foil for the West, whose self-perceived superiority relies heavily on its Eastern counterpart. However, this discourse of exoticism, essentialism, and stereotyping of the East and its people has historically justified colonization, exploitation, and violence against Eastern civilizations.

The Orientalized Gaze: Gender and the Western Discursive Construction of the 'Orient'

Introduction

The representation of the 'Orient' in Western narratives extends back to antiquity, with Edward Said locating its origins in ancient Greek literature (Said, xxii). Employing Aeschylus' The Persians as an example, Said elucidates how Asia was portrayed as a 'hostile other,' a realm beyond the known, invariably characterized by inferiority in contrast to a self-confident West. Furthermore, Said argues that this historical process involves not only the construction of the East by the West, but also the subsequent perpetuation of this discourse through a variety of literary, political, and academic domains, creating an "Orientalism" that justifies and reinforces Western dominance (Said, 5-6). 

Nevertheless, existing critiques of Orientalism seldom address the central role of gender in the construction of these discourses. As a consequence, the ways in which the gendered identities of colonized women have been manipulated to serve Western imperialist interests remain underexplored. In response, this paper aims to extend Said's analytical framework to incorporate the nexus between gender and imperialism, exploring how the Western discursive configuration of colonized women has reinforced and justified modes of subjugation and control. 

1. The Power of Orientalized Discourse: Hegemony, Subjugation, and Gendered Exclusion

Building on Said's insights, a multitude of scholars have sought to unravel the ways in which the 'Orient' has remained subjected to the representational whims of a hegemonic West. However, relatively few analyses have integrated the intersection of gender into their examinations. To remedy this omission, this section will synthesize key findings from studies that probe the gendered dimensions of Orientalism, assessing how the exclusion and marginalization of women in these accounts has served to support and legitimize colonial projects.

2. The Myth of the Passive, Submissive Oriental: Rescuing and Civilizing the Colonized Female

One of the most widespread stereotypes perpetuated within Orientalist discourse is the image of the colonized woman as passive, submissive, and in need of rescue. This section will explore how this depiction served to validate Western imperialism under the guise of emancipation, examining the narratives forged by British, French, and American authors that justify colonial interventions as necessary steps toward 'uplifting' and 'civilizing' these "oppressed" women.

3. Contested Identities: Resisting and Transforming the Gendered Orientalizing Gaze

Despite the pervasive and persuasive nature of the Orientalized gaze, colonized women have not been mere passive recipients of these imposed identities. This section will foreground the resistance and subversion that emerged from the colonized themselves, spotlighting the ways in which women from colonized contexts have challenged, reworked, and undermined the gendered tropes that have long defined them. By assessing the writings of women from the 'Orient,' this discussion will illuminate the complexities and contradictions that lie beneath the monolithic narratives propagated by the West.

4. Conclusion: Re-envisioning the 'Orient' Through a Gendered Lens

As this paper has demonstrated, the influence of the Western ideological apparatus upon colonized women has been far from benign. The gendered constructions that infuse Orientalist.discourse have directly contributed to systems of domination and control that have consistently marginalized and disadvantaged colonized populations. By unpacking these dynamics and foregrounding the voices of women from the 'Orient,' it becomes possible to re-envision the East in terms that resist the reductive and simplistic myths perpetuated by the West. In doing so, this research ultimately seeks to contribute to ongoing conversations that challenge, dismantle, and transform the legacies of Orientalist discourse, fostering deeper engagements with the rich and multifaceted realities of the world's diverse cultures and peoples.

Title: Reconceptualizing Orientalism: The Interplay of Gender and Imperialism in Western Literary Discourse

Introduction
The construction of the 'Orient' in Western narratives has persisted since antiquity, with Edward Said tracing its origins to Ancient Greece, as evidenced by Aeschylus' plays (Said, 5-6). He posits that the West's portrayal of the 'Orient' perpetuates a biased image arising from an inherent power imbalance, which in turn reinforces Western dominance. However, Said's seminal work does not specifically address gender as a contributing factor to this discourse. Thus, this paper aims to expand upon his work by scrutinizing the role of gender in European literary representations of colonized women, and how the notion of 'rescuing' and 'civilizing' them provided a rationale for enhancing imperial power. Incorporating the intersection of gender and imperialism will facilitate a comprehensive reevaluation of how Western narratives have shaped- and continue to impact - the perception of the 'Orient.'

1. Intersecting Power Dynamics: Gender and Imperialism in Orientalist Discourse
To fully comprehend the complexity of Orientalist discourse, it is vital to grasp the intertwined relationship between gender and imperialism. This section will review existing literature and analyze how the portrayal of women in colonized societies has been exploited to justify the expansion and retention of imperial power. By integrating the gendered perspective, a more holistic understanding of the power dynamics underlying Orientalist discourse can be achieved.

2. The 'Other' Woman: The Portrayal of Colonized Women in European Literature
This section investigates how European literary narratives have wielded imagery of colonized women as instruments of imperialist ideology. Analyzing various works, it will demonstrate how the depiction of women has been manipulated to suture a fabricated moral obligation to 'rescue' and 'civilize,' which subsequently provided an impetus to impose colonial rule.

3. Undoing the Orientalist Gaze: Resistance and Subversion in the Creative Works of Colonized Women
While colonized women have primarily been subjects of Orientalist discourse, they have not remained passive recipients. Herein, we explore the diverse ways in which these women have resisted and subverted gendered constructs imposed upon them. By studying the creative works of writers from colonized contexts, this section will provide a platform for their voices to contest the preexisting narrative and reshape the framework.

4. The Reevaluation of Orientalism: Gender as a Catalyst for Discursive Progress
By investigating the underlying power dynamics and the portrayal of colonized women in European literature, this paper demonstrates the need to reconceptualize Orientalist discourse by incorporating the often-overlooked factor of gender. This reevaluation has implications for further understanding the intricacies surrounding the Orientalist framework and will facilitate new perspectives on contemporary cross-cultural relations.

Conclusion
Orientalism, as a discourse, has yielded considerable influence in shaping the perceptions of the 'Orient.' By highlighting the interplay between gender and imperialism, this paper contributes to the deconstruction and evaluation of the power dynamics underlying this discourse. An examination of colonized women's resistance and subversion in creative works showcases the agency to challenge the established narrative. Consequently, integrating a gendered perspective leads to a more comprehensive understanding of the Orientalist discourse, facilitating a progressive dialogue toward overcoming colonial legacies and fostering cross-cultural empathy.

Orientalism, Gender, and Imperialism: Deconstructing Western Literary Representations

Essentially, the Orientalist discourse is contingent upon a distinct power dynamic that enables the West to create and maintain reductive images of the East. Exercising control over the Orient’s representation, the West situates itself as the observer, imbued with the power to discipline by defining what the East is and is not. The “power/knowledge” nexus – the notion that the production, dissemination, and control of knowledge serve as primary agents of power is reminiscent of the Panopticon, wherein the West becomes the observer, the bearer of the power-laden gaze, determining the Eastern identity, norms, morals and interests. This gaze reifies “a grid of intelligibility that legitimates specific research as objective knowledge.”

Fundamentally, Orientalist discourse relies on a unique power dynamic that allows the West to construct and perpetuate simplistic depictions of the East. By dominating representations of the Orient, the West positions itself as an authoritative observer, endowed with the ability to regulate and define Eastern identity, culture, and values. This relationship is reflective of the "power/knowledge" nexus, in which the creation, circulation, and management of knowledge function as primary mechanisms of control. It bears striking parallels to the Panopticon, where the West assumes the role of an all-seeing observer, wielding a power-infused gaze that shapes the Eastern character, norms, morals, and interests. This omnipresent scrutiny serves to reinforce a framework of understanding that validates specific research as objective knowledge.

In essence, Orientalist discourse hinges upon a particular power dynamic that permits the West to generate and sustain reductive portrayals of the East. By exerting authority over depictions of the Orient, the West asserts itself as a discerning observer, possessing the capability to regulate and delineate Eastern identity, culture, and values. This relationship mirrors the "power/knowledge" nexus, wherein the genesis, propagation, and governance of knowledge act as principal instruments of domination. The paradigm closely aligns with the Panopticon, as the West adopts the stance of a vigilant observer, brandishing a gaze imbued with power to mold Eastern nature, norms, morals, and interests. Such comprehensive surveillance underpins a system of comprehension that legitimizes particular research as unbiased knowledge.
